On 7 September 2020, about 300 supporters and activists of the Butun Kyrgyzstan political party protested outside the Sverdlovsky district court in Bishkek city, calling for the court to rule in favor of their party in their lawsuit case against the Central Election Commission that rejected Butun Kyrgyzstan party's bid to participate in the parliamentary election which is scheduled for 4 October 2020. [size=about 300]

On 7 September 2020, a group of intoxicated policemen physically attacked and assaulted several civilians at the parking lot of the supermarket in Osh city which triggered police investigation of the incident.

On 6 September 2020, a 51-year-old detainee from Nookat district was tortured by three police officers to obtain a forced confession in the police station near the town of Nookat in Osh region. The victim filed a complaint with the district prosecutor's office in October.

On 4 September 2020, 20-30 defaulting borrowers protested outside the White House in Bishkek city demanding the Kyrgyz government intervene in their disputes with banks and financial organisations to write off interest rate payments on their loans. [size=20-30]

On 4 September 2020, a serviceman of the military base N36806 in Osh city deserted his base after suffering physical assault from the commanding officer on the premises leaving a suicide note. He was located and brought back to the base on 5 September.

On 1 September 2020, about 200 supporters and opponents of the Kyrgyzstan political faction and several political party activists, including Ata Meken party, protested outside the country's Supreme Court in Bishkek city calling for the court to rule in favour of Kyrgyzstan party to run in the parliamentary election while opponents urged the authorities to reject Kyrgyzstan Party's bid and preserve the integrity of October election. [size=about 200]

On 1 September 2020, about 150 retail clothing shop owners protested outside the country's parliament in Bishkek city against the online auction of their retail lots at the Karavan shopping centre demanding the Kyrgyz government cancel the online auction and assist protesters with rent and loan payments after coronavirus quarantine. [size=about 150]

On 27 August 2020, 40-50 activists of the several political factions including Kyrgyzstan party supporters protested outside the State Administrative Court in Bishkek city calling for the court to allow the party participate in October parliamentary election while activists of other political factions. [size=40-50]

On 27 August 2020, dozens of The Kyrgyzstan Party supporters demonstrated in Tokmok city against The Central Election Commission's decision to reject the party's bid for upcoming October parliamentary election in the country. Earlier in a week, CEC ruled Kyrgyzstan party failed to register by the deadline which sparked a protest at the CEC headquarters in Bishkek city. [size=dozens]

On 25 August 2020, about 100 activists of the various political parties including Kyrgyzstan political party gathered outside the office of the Central Election Commission in Bishkek city protesting the denial of Kyrgyzstan party's bid to run in the upcoming parliamentary election after failing to register by the deadline which Kyrgyzstan party supporters refuted. [size=about 100]

On 24 August 2020, 15-20 defaulting loan borrowers demonstrated outside the UN office in Bishkek city calling for UN involvement in their disputes with the financial organizations and private loan businesses to address bail out for borrowers during coronavirus emergency in Kyrgyzstan. [size=15-20]

On 17 August 2020, about 10 protesters demonstrated outside the embassy of Belarus in Bishkek city against violence toward protesters in Minsk calling for solidarity with the anti-government protest movement in Belarus. [size=about 10]

On 17 August 2020, about 50 residents of Kok-Tash village protested outside the district court in Batken town demanding release of four of their fellow villagers who were detained in January for alleged involvement in border-related clashes. [size=about 50]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security

On 11 August 2020, agents of the Kyrgyz State Committee for National Security physically suffocated an Uzbek journalist Bobomurad Abdullayev in Bishkek city while he was in custody for an extradition request from the Uzbek government. The incident took place after Abdullayev refused to cooperate with the investigator on the extradition procedure.

On 7 August 2020, about 70 small retail business owners protested outside the White House in Bishkek city against the government's plan to auction Karavan shopping center demanding the authorities put in on hold and assist protesters with rent fees which they weren't able to pay during coronavirus quarantine. [size=about 70]
On 6 August 2020, a Kyrgyz border guard was shot and wounded in Eki-Tash locality in Batken district of Batken region. Gunshots came from the Tajik side.

On 6 August 2020, a Kyrgyz villager was shot and wounded in Zhaka-Oruk locality near the village of Kok-Tash in Batken district of Batken region on the disputed border between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. Attackers remained unknown.

On 3 August 2020, 20-30 passenger minibus drivers protested at the western bus terminal in Bishkek city against the Kyrgyz government's double standards during coronavirus quarantine which protesters complained left them jobless while illegal bus operators continue carrying passengers between the regions. Protesters demanded the authorities shut down other bus operators as well. [size=20-30]

On 29 July 2020, 15-20 employees of the Issyk-Kul regional Forestry Department protested outside headquarters in Ananyevo village in Issyk-Kul region against head of the department demanding his dismissal over allegations of corruption. [size=15-20]

On 29 July 2020, about 65 protesters including relatives of a murder victim demonstrated outside the Mayor's Office in the town of Uzgen in Osh region demanding justice served in local cab driver murder case. [size=about 65]

On 28 July 2020, about 6 entrepreneurs gathered in At-Bashi township of Naryn region in protest of spreading rumors that their investment project is funded by Chinese investor. Protesters called for the local anti-China activist Timur Makhmudov to stop injecting false information regarding their meat and milk plant in the district. [size=about 6]

On 28 July 2020, about 50 workers of the municipal bus company protested at the bus terminal in Bishkek city against low wages and pay delays demanding the city authorities intervene to resolve protesters' concerns for timely pay and salaries in full. [size=about 50]

On 24 July 2020, 50-60 residents of Talas district protested outside the Jerooy gold mine camp in Talas region demanding the company shut down its operations for coronavirus quarantine after one of its workers died of pneumonia which protesters feared may spread in the district. [size=50-60]

On 23 July 2020, about 20 local activists protested on the North-South motroway in the village of Kuyruchuk in Jumgal district of Naryn region against poor quality road construction work on the section of motorway, demanding the authorities to probe the construction firm for doing an improper job. [size=about 20]

On 19 July 2020, several citizens of Pakistan were attacked and assaulted by 5-6 rioters at the mountain resort near the village of Koi-Tash in Alamudun district of Chui region after verbal altercation between groups which resulted in Pakistani nationals seeking medical aid in Bishkek city. [size=5-6]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-); Government of Kyrgyzstan (2017-)

On 18 July 2020, a 42-year-old male was attacked by a group of villagers in the town of Koi-Tash of Alamudun district of Chui region after altercation over summer home building in the village which was met by hostility in the neighborhood. The victim reported that a policeman and a local councilman were among attackers. [size=no report]

On 14 July 2020, an automobile belonging to the Tajik representative of the Vorukh township administration of Sughd region was attacked by a group of Kyrgyz nationals on Isfara-Vorukh motor road while driving through the Kyrgyz territory [Batken coded with GP2]. Kyrgyz villagers threw rocks at the vehicle destroying its rear window. [size=no report]

On 13 July 2020, about 7 protesters were detained by police on Ala Too main square in Bishkek city for attempting to demonstrate against upcoming parliamentary elections in October 2020. Protesters demanded voting to be rescheduled due to coronavirus emergency. [size=about 7]

On 13 July 2020, young male resident of Bishkek city reported police brutality incident at the Pervomaysky police station in Bishkek city after he was detained at the Ala Too square. Victim complained he was transported to the station where three officers assaulted him using chokehold. Police denied assault incident.

On 8 July 2020, 20-30 residents and farmers of Turk-Abad village in Suzak district of Jalal-Abad region protested against unfair distribution of agricultural land in the district demanding the local authorities intervene in their dispute with the landowner and allow farmers raise crops without sublease. [size=20-30]

On 3 July 2020, about 10 residents of Esenjan Saparbekov street in the village of Chaek of Jumgal district in Naryn region protested against bad roads in the neighborhood demanding the local administration fix the roads and restrict traffic for heavy duty trucks in the area. [size=about 10]

Around 29 June 2020, several members of a Kyrgyz family protested in Kok-Tash village, Batken, against the Tajik border guards authorizing the demolition of their concrete fence by the Tajik villagers on the disputed Kyrgyz-Tajik borde. [size=several]

On 29 June 2020, about 500 protesters marched through downtown Bishkek city to gather on main Ala-Too square in protest of a legislative bill, claiming that if signed, it would restrict freedom of speech. Protesters demanded Kyrgyz president reject it. [size=about 500]

On 29 June 2020, about 20 residents of Ishkavan village in Kara-Suu district of Osh region protested near their homes against lack of water supply in town demanding the local authorities to address concerns regarding limited access to drinking water. [size=about 20]

On 25 June 2020, about 20 activists protested outside the White House in Bishkek city against the legislative bill in the country's parliament which if passed would curb freedom of speech in Kyrgyzstan, protesters argued. Activists called for lawmakers to reject it. [size=about 20]

On 22 June 2020, about 50 residents of Chui region protested outside the central government's main office near Panfilov park in Bishkek city demanding the authorities to legalize their land plots. [size=about 50]

On 21 June 2020, about 30 residents of Tokmok city protested outside the city police station after hit-and-run fatal incident day earlier which protesters suspected was in the process of cover up involving local police. Protesters demanded police officials come out to meet them and process victim's relatives' complaint to press charges against suspected driver. [size=about 30]

On 20 June 2020, about 10 drivers of passenger minibuses protested at the western bus terminal in Bishkek city against the government's plan to shut down public transportation between the cities and districts after recent increase of coronavirus infections in the country. Protesters demanded their businesses remain open for operation since they are complying with public health requirements during an emergency. [size=about 10]

On 19 June 2020, about 15 protesters demonstrated outside the Prosecutor General's Office in Bishkek city in support of small businesses demanding the Kyrgyz authorities provide assistance to businesses and the country's Business-Ombudsman help them with eliminating bureaucracy in the government. [size=about 15]

On 19 June 2020, about 20 protesters demonstrated outside the city court in Talas city against a judge whom protesters accused of corruption after main suspect in fatal car accident case was acquitted of criminal charges. Protesters argued a judge was bribed in exchange for favorable verdict. [size=about 20]

On 19 June 2020, about 10 residents of Tepe-Korgon village in Aravan district of Osh region protested against the local councilman whom protesters allegedly gave $2500 each in exchange for land plots to build homes but they have never been reciprocated. Protesters called for the authorities to intervene and assist them to retrieve their payments. [size=about 10]

On 18 June 2020, about 15 nursing home employees protested on the premises near Akhunbaev street in Bishkek city against lay-offs, pay cuts and long working hours demanding care facility's manager improve working conditions at the nursing home and increase wages. [size=about 15]

On 17 June 2020, about 50 residents of Kadamjai district protested outside the town administration's office in Kyzyl-Kia township against the nearby coal mine auction which left them jobless. Protesters complained they have loans to pay and the coal mine was providing jobs until it was sold to the private businesses. [size=about 50]

On 16 June 2020, about 300 residents of Ken-Bulun village in Chui region protested against the local police and court failure to investigate an assault incident which took place 2 days earlier when nearby restaurant security guards attacked fellow villagers. [size=about 300]

On 15 June 2020, about 30 women's rights activists protested violence targeting women, by gathering outside the Kyrgyz parliament in Bishkek city, after a video showing a spouse abuse case in Suzak was largely shared in the social media. [size=about 30]

On 14 June 2020, about 50 residents and livestock farmers protested at the Kara-Kujur valley near the village of Jerge-Tal in Naryn district of Naryn region against the local administration's plan to extend shared use of Kara-Kujur pastures for cattle farmers. Protesters categorically opposed an extension arguing there is a shortage of grazing land in the area. [size=about 50]

On 11 June 2020, a Kaktus Media journalist was attacked and chokeholded by a private security guard at the Kainar restaurant on Sukhe Bator street in Bishkek city after reporter attempted to record a gathering of the government officials and lawmakers on his camera at the location.

On 10 June 2020, about 40 employees of the Panfilov park in Bishkek city protested on the premises demanding the city authorities reopen the park for business after coronavirus quarantine. [size=about 40]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 9 June 2020, about 20 supporters of former Prime-Minister Sapar Isakov protested outside the Pervomaisky district court in Bishkek city demanding his release from detention. Isakov was sentenced to 18 years in prison on mainly corruption charges which former official denied. [size=about 20]

On 8 June 2020, about 50 semi-truck drivers protested outside the regional administration's office in Osh city against corruption on the Kyrgyz-Chinese border post Erkeshtam reportedly affecting their operations. Drivers alleged the Chinese company Abu-Sahiy trucks were given preferential treatment over Kyrgyz drivers which protesters called unfair. [size=about 50]

On 8 June 2020, about 5 activists protested outside the Mayor's Office in Osh city demanding the city administration schedule a meeting for them with the country's president who is expected to arrive in the city on 10 June. Protesters urged the authorities to hear them out to discuss the social issues in the city. [size=about 5]

On 8 June 2020, about 20 protesters demonstrated outside the Pervomayski district court in Bishkek city demanding former president Almazbek Atambayev brought to justice for his alleged crimes and abuse of power while in office. [size=about 20]

Property destruction: On 7 June 2020, an unknown group of arsonists threw Molotov cocktails into the local office of the independent Channel-3 broadcasting station in the town of Talas, very early in the morning. TV station's journalists insisted was directly connected to their work. Director of Channel-3 indicated that about $15,000 worth of equipment was destroyed in fire.

On 5 June 2020, about 170 residents and farmers of Jerge-Tal village in Naryn district of Naryn region blocked the local road to Kum-Bel pastures in protest of unresolved dispute regarding limited access to grazing land for out of town cattle farmers. [size=about 170]

On 5 June 2020, about 20 residents of Osor village near Jatan Township in Nookat district of Osh region protested against the local businessman's mining project on the dry bed of the nearby Kyrk-Kol river which protesters complained is altering water flow and threatening their properties along the river. [size=about 20]

On 3 June 2020, about 30 residents of Chaek village in Jumgal district of Naryn region protested near their homes demanding the local authorities shutdown nearby landfill, provide aid to the households that have been affected by flashflood day before, fix drinking water supply and clean up irrigation canals in the village. [size=about 30]

On 2 June 2020, a Kyrgyz national was rushed to the hospital after sustaining a gunshot wound while driving on Osh-Isfana motor road in Eki-Tash neighborhood near Samarkandyk village of Batken district in Batken region. Multiple hunting rifle fire shots were discharged from the territory of Tajikistan by unknown individuals who were shooting at the Kyrgyz citizen's automobile. [size=unknown]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 1 June 2020, about 15 protesters demonstrated outside the Pervomaysky district court in Bishkek city against former president Almazbek Atambayev demanding justice for his alleged crimes and abuse of power while in office. Simultaneously, a group of supporters of former president including his family members gathered at the same location demanding his release from detention. [size=about 15]

On 31 May 2020, about 20 residents of a neighborhood protested outside the Kyrgyz-Turkish medical clinic in Bishkek city against the plan to treat patients with coronavirus at the location. Protesters demanded infected patients taken elsewhere out of fear of possible spread of infection in the neighborhood. [size=about 20]

On 31 May 2020, a riot broke out between dozens of Kyrgyz and Uzbek nationals after dispute regarding access to water source near the village of Chechme in Kadamjai district of Batken region on the border with Uzbekistan near the village of Chashma in Sokh enclave. Rioters hurled rocks at each other while setting few properties on fire on both sides of the border. 200 Uzbek citizens were hospitalized in Sokh enclave including 13 with gunshot wounds and 25 Kyrgyz villagers were taken to the hospital in Kadamjai district with injuries of various degrees. [size=thousands]

On 29 May 2020, 20-30 residents of Voenno-Antonovka village protested outside the district administration's office in the town of Sokuluk of Chui region demanding the authorities legalize their land plots which has been a long-standing issue for them to build homes due to the Kyrgyz government's ban to build properties on the disputed land. [size=20-30]

On 28 May 2020, about 50 quarantined female patients of the perinatal clinic protested at the city hospital in Osh city demanding release from observation since their test results came back negative for coronavirus on two occasions. Protesters complained they cannot take care of their newborns properly due to poor conditions in the hospital. [size=about 50]

On 28 May 2020, 15-20 residents of Chon-Daly village in Ysyk-Ata district of Chui region protested against the local gravel pit mine which protesters complained was negatively impacting their village due to collateral dust blanketing their homes. Protesters demanded the local authorities resolve their public health and environmental concerns. [size=15-20]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 24 May 2020, an exchange of fire occurred between Kyrgyz and Tajik border troops at the Sungan-Baba pastureland near Ak-Sai village in Batken district after initial confrontation between Tajik herders from Vorukh exclave and Kyrgyz border guards about the use of a pasture land during which shots were fired by an unknown gunman from the Tajik side. Tajik authorities claimed that the brief exchange of fire resulted in one Tajik civilian wounded on the Tajik side.

On 22 May 2020, about 40 residents of Ak-Kya village in Ak-Talaa district of Naryn region protested against coronavirus quarantine roadblocks in the village demanding the local authorities remove them and let the farmers and villagers go back to work in the field due to a season in full swing. Protesters complained the medical teams shouldn't work at night to transport infected patients out of town and do so during day hours. [size=about 40]

On 22 May 2020, about 6 rights activists protested outside the White House in Bishkek city against the legislative bill in the country's parliament, which if passed, would oblige NGOs to provide financial and personnel records, including funding sources, to the Kyrgyz government. Protesters complained they were denied access to the parliament hearing which they have requested prior to demonstration. [size=about 6]

On 18 May 2020, about 10 villagers of the town of Telman in Chui region protested as they found the price of locally produced milk set by the wholesalers very low. Protesters demanded local authorities to get involved to resolve the issue. [size=about 10]

On 18 May 2020, dozens of quarantined rioters, who previously arrived from Russia, attacked medics and attempted to vandalize an ambulance vehicle at a coronavirus observation facility close to the Manas airport near Dacha-Suu hamlet in Sokuluk district of Chui region. The incident took place after unconfirmed rumors spread in the camp that some infected patients have been dicharged and allowed to continue self-isolation at home which then sparked a riot. [size=dozens]

On 18 May 2020, 50-100 residents of Jeti-Oguz village in Issyk-Kul region protested against the local authorities plan to use the village clinic as an observation facility for patients that may have been infected with coronavirus. Protesters opposed the plan and demanded such facility operates elsewhere in the district but not in their town. [size=50-100]

On 17 May 2020, after policeman approached a group of people in the Tuleberdiyev park in Bishkek city and warned them to obey social distancing rules due to a threat of coronavirus infection in the city, the group got agressive and attempted to get hold of the police officer's service handgun during a physical confrontation. Policeman shot in the air to disperse a crowd. [size=no report]

On 16 May 2020, about 3 protesters demonstrated on Ala-Too main square in Bishkek city demanding reforms in the Kyrgyz government after coronavirus emergency in the country. Protesters insisted the Kyrgyz authorities have done little to help citizens in need during quarantine across the nation. [size=about 3]

Around 15 May 2020, a 38-year-old male was repeatedly tortured and assaulted by police officers in the detention facility of the Jalal-Abad city police department which left the victim with multiple physical injuries, including concussion and kidney trauma, and psychological stress. The victim's legal representative filed a lawsuit with Pervomaysky district court in Bishkek city seeking compensation.

On 9 May 2020, more than 50 residents of Acha-Kaindy village in At-Bashy district of Naryn region protested in the vicinity against coronavirus quarantine lockdown in their town as it reportedly impeded their seasonal farming work and activity near or outside the village. Protesters called for the Kyrgyz authorities to remove police roadblocks. [size=more than 50]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 8 May 2020, about 30-40 Kyrgyz and Tajik villagers engaged in a fight where they throw stones at each other with occasional firing from rifles, in a disputed area on the Kyrgyz-Tajik border(Batken center is coded with GP2) over a dispute on a land in Chek neighborhood near Kok-Tash village of Batken. A Kyrgyz villager was inured from the head. The Kyrgyz border guards fired warning shots to disperse crowd and critically injuring two Tajik citizens. Following this, while the event was still going on, Tajik border guards firing mortar shells on the Kyrgyz side wounding 3 Kyrgyz border troops.

On 8 May 2020, about 15 workers protested outside the Meade company's office in Vostok village of Alamudun district in Chui region demanding their back pay which they have been trying to receive from the firm for more than a week. Protesters complained they need money to pay for food and rent during coronavirus emergency in the country and urged the Kyrgyz authorities to intervene in their case. [size=about 15]
On 7 May 2020, 15-20 residents of Telman village in Ysyk-Ata district protested against decrease in the milk prices, set by the wholesalers whom protesters sell it to. [size=15-20]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 1 May 2020, Kyrgyz border guards fired warning shots in the air near Apkan village in Batken district while Uzbek villagers from Sokh enclave of Uzbekistan are herding their cattle in a disputed border area. According to the villagers, they have been using the area for a long time while Kyrgyz government claimed that they wanted to prevent the villagers using Kyrgyz lands.

Around 25 April 2020, a 36-year-old resident of the Kochkor-Ata village was tortured by police officers of the Nooken district police station in the town of Massy of Jalal-Abad region over alleged embezzlement allegations at the Kyrgyzneftegaz company.

On 24 April 2020, 20-30 villagers and farmers protested at the nearby police quarantine roadblock as part of coronavirus measures in the village of Jany-Jer in Batken district, against the lack of irrigation water supply which protesters insisted is having a negative impact on their crop fields. Protesters demanded the local authorities resolve the issue. [size=20-30]

On 18 April 2020, an unknown gunman or gunmen opened fire at the road block in the village of Arashan outside Bishkek city after the voluntary village guards refused to let through 9-10 people on quadracycles who were attempting to cross the village via main road. Previously, road block was installed by the village community to keep outsiders out of town due to coronavirus emergency in the country. [size=9-10]

On 4 April 2020, a villager of Ak-Buura town in Kara-Suu district of Osh region was physically attacked by the residents of the nearby Uchar village after he refused to let Uchar villagers through a roadblock at the entrance of the town. The roadblock was voluntarily installed by the local community to keep out the possibly infected people with coronavirus. The victim was hospitalized with injures. [size=several]

On 1 April 2020, 15-20 city residents protested outside the Sverdlov district police station in Bishkek city demanding their applications for coronavirus quarantine passes processed without delays. Police official told them it is taking an extra day to issue passes due to backlog. [size=15-20]

On 1 April 2020, a group of unknown people broke the windows of the children's summer camp building in the village of Mayak in Tup district of Issyk-Kul region. It was a possibility that the attackers were part of the movement opposing the authorities' initial plan to open a quarantine facility at the summer camp for infected or possibly infected patients with coronavirus.

On 1 April 2020, a group of Mayak village residents protested against the local authorities' plan to open a quarantine facility for possibly infected with coronavirus patients near their village in Tup district of Issyk-Kul region. The local authorities were forced to abandon the plan after demonstrations. [size=no report]

On 31 March 2020, a group of residents of the Pole Chudes neighbourhood in Novopavlovka village of Sokuluk district in Chui region blocked the local road in protest after increased traffic through their neighbourhood due to coronavirus quarantine. Protesters complained dishonest car drivers use the road to evade quarantine police roadblocks on a nearby main highway in order to enter Bishkek city without official passes which are mandatorily issued by the authorities. [size=no report]

On 31 March 2020, more than dozen of Mayak village residents protested against the local authorities initiated plan to open a coronavirus quarantine facility for possibly infected patients near their village in Tup district of Issyk-Kul region. Protesters expressed worries they may get infected if a quarantine facility goes into operation. [size=more than dozen]

On 30 March 2020, a civilian was allegedly beaten by the police officer on the premises of the Oktyabrsky district police station in Bishkek city, which was recorded by anonymous source and then posted on the social media. The Ministry of Interior of Kyrgyzstan launched a probe to review an incident. Motive unknown.

On 25 March 2020, the Kyrgyz government has introduced curfew from 8pm to 7am in the city of Bishkek, Osh, Jalal-Abad, Suzak, Kara-Suu and Nookat cities till 15 April due to coronavirus outbreak in the country. Movement is restricted for city residents during curfew hours. Citizens are allowed to go out during the day hours for food shopping or purchase medicines at the local pharmacies. Police roadblocks with medical teams on duty are installed around the city perimeter to restrict the inbound car traffic. City residents will face legal implications for breaking curfew rules during emergency period. On 14 April 2020, Kyrgyz president extended a state of emergency in Kyrgyzstan until 30 April. On 28 April 2020, the Kyrgyz government has extended coronavirus quarantine in Bishkek, Osh, Jajal-Abad cities and At-Bashi district in Naryn region until 10 May 2020.

On 21 March 2020, 20-30 quarantined Kyrgyz citizens protested on the premises of the observation facility near Manas airport outside Bishkek city demanding the authorities let them leave and continue their isolation in their homes after testing negative to coronavirus infection on arrival from abroad. [size=20-30]

On 12 March 2020, 30-40 residents of Chym-Korgon village in Kemin district of Chui region protested outside the local administration's office against negligent transfer of 1 km border to the neighboring Kazakhstan. Protesters claimed the local construction businesses mine rubble and stone from the banks of nearby river that divides the two countries which resulted in riverbed changing its direction. The local administration officials told protesters the special commission was created to investigate the issue. [size=30-40]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security

On 12 March 2020, the police captain of Tup district police department was detained, assaulted and tortured by the state security service agents near the town of Tup in Issyk-Kul region. The victim was arrested due to a drug offense related case.

On 11 March 2020, a group of Kyrgyz villagers protested against the Uzbek villagers, who intruded into the Kyrgyz territory in Tash-Aryk village near the town of Tengi in Ala-Buka district of Jalal-Abad region, to dig a small aqueduct which would open access to water source on the Kyrgyz side. The Kyrgyz villagers demanded the Uzbek villagers stop digging to which the Uzbek villagers claimed it's their territory. [size=a group]

On 10 March 2020, about 100 protesters, mostly women, demonstrated near the monument to Urkuya Saliyeva in Bishkek city business district against domestic violence and violence against women in Kyrgyzstan. Protest followed 8 March women's march when female activists were attacked by Kyrk Choro conservative group members and detention of women by the city police for marching. [size=about 100]

On 10 March 2020, about 8 women activists demonstrated against domestic violence and for gender equality on Chyngyz Aitmatov square in Karakol city following attacks on women activists in Bishkek city on 8 March. [size=about 8]
BFI: Bishkek Feminist Initiatives Association; Women (Kyrgyzstan); Journalists (Kyrgyzstan)

On 8 March 2020, Kyrk Choro nationalist group rioters threw eggs at Bishkek Feminist Initiative Association activists near the Eternal Flame memorial in Bishkek city. There were reports of some other unknown rioters wearing masks who attempted to grab and drag women activists. They were not identified. It was later known that some Kyrk Choro members were fined. No reports of police intervention to rioters. [size=unknown]

On 8 March 2020, about 10 protesters demonstrated outside the Sverdlov district police station in Bishkek city demanding release of all detained women activists who were arrested near the Eternal Flame memorial hours earlier. Protesters chanted Freedom to women! and Shame on police!. [size=about 10]

On 3 March 2020, more than 100 protesters, mostly women, demonstrated outside the Karavan shopping center in Bishkek city appealing to the Kyrgyz president to help with protecting their shops from the upcoming auction which was set forward by the state agency that oversees seized properties. Protesters accused the head of the state agency of corruption involving the shopping center itself. [size=more than 100]

On 2 March 2020, about 1500 supporters of imprisoned former lawmaker Sadyr Japarov demonstrated on the Ala-Too square in Bishkek city demanding his release and reforms of the country's judiciary. Police forces intervened with teargas while demonstrators responded by hurling rocks at security forces, damaging cars and businesses in the area. Dozens of protesters were detained. [size=about 1500]

On 2 March 2020, several women attempted to hit the employees of the Kyrgyz parliament and presidential administration at the entrance gate to the White House in Bishkek city. The women had left a demonstration on Ala Too square on the same day, for the release of imprisoned former lawmaker Sadyr Japarov. [size=several]
KFTU: Kyrgyzstan Federation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (Kyrgyzstan)

On 25 February 2020, about 200 protesters from different unions demonstrated outside the Kyrgyzstan Federation of Trade Unions headquarters on Chuy avenue in Bishkek city business district demanding resignation of the organization's president. Protesters insisted that he holds a position illegally and there's a confict of interest involving real estate deals belonging to the Trade Union. [size=about 200]

On 23 February 2020, more than 20 residents of the village of Kabak near Tabylgyty town, protested on the premises of the Chinese road construction company's project demanding all Chinese workers leave the area out of fear of coronavirus pandemic. Head of the Kabak village administration reassured the protesters that the Chinese workers will be confined within their camp area and there will be no contact between the villagers and Chinese nationals from then on. [size=more than 20]

On 22 February 2020, 15-20 residents of Uchar village in Kara-Suu district protested against illegal home building activity in the outskirts of town demanding to stop any construction works due to a risk of seasonal flashflood which protesters argued is likely to happen if illegal construction persists without oversight. [size=15-20]

On 21 February 2020, about 60 students of the sports school and their parents protested at the school in Karakol city against the planned closure of the school. Protesters said it is needed for the local community and children. [size=about 60]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 21 February 2020, 15-20 supporters of the former Kyrgyz president Almazbek Atambayev, who was charged with murder and multiple counts of corruption and abuse of power while in office, protested outside the country's state security service GKNB headquarters in Bishkek city demanding his hospitalization due to reports of his deteriorating health in detention facility. [size=15-20]

On 19 February 2020, about 20 supporters of the Aknet internet provider company's founder gathered outside the Kyrgyz parliament in Bishkek city to protest against the arrest of the company founder. Protesters said company executive was intimidated to sell his stake. [size=about 20]

On 18 February 2020, 5-10 activists including a former Kyrgyz lawmaker demonstrated outside the embassy of Tajikistan in Bishkek city in protest of the Tajik police general recently claiming that Batken region in Kyrgyzstan has never been a part of Kyrgyz land in the past, talking about the disputed border between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. [size=5-10]

On 17 February 2020, 300-400 local villagers protested against the Chinese investment logistics hub project in At-Bashi district of eastern Naryn region in Kyrgyzstan. Protesters said that there is an information about 200 hectares of land that was already given to China for the project and the local Kyrgyz villagers are categorically against it. [size=300-400]

On 16 February 2020, about 30 residents protested in Ozgur village of Osh region demanding the local authorities resolve their land dispute with the private company. Protesters said this dispute has been in the courts since 2016 and has yet to come to a conclusion. [size=about 30]

On 15 February 2020, public protest against the Chinese investor-funded logistics hub project took place in At-Bashi town of At-Bashy district in Naryn region of Kyrgyzstan. Protesters demanded the Kyrgyz government show them an official document which clarifies whether the land was leased to the Chinese company. [size=no report]

On 13 February 2020, a group attempted to disrupt a meeting of activists in Ololohaus building in Osh city by intruding and demanding a meeting dismissed. One of the intruders was physically trying to grab an activist's smartphone and shouting everyone must leave. The disrupters were reportedly misled and thought that it was an LGBTI meeting. [size=a group]

On 10 February 2020, 15-20 protesters demonstrated outside the White House in Bishkek city demanding the Kyrgyz authorities hold the judge of the Tokmok city court accountable as he ruled to acquit two murder suspects in an alleged killing case in 2016. [size=15-20]

On 10 February 2020, about 1000 homeowners demonstrated in Ak-Ordo neighborhood of Sokuluk district, demanding legalization of their homes and the government's assistance with building roads in the neighborhood and social infrustructure. Protesters complained their grievances haven't been heard by the Kyrgyz officials for more than 10 years. [size=about 1000]

On 10 February 2020, about 200 local villagers of the town of Sogondu in Alai district of Osh region protested against the nearby Taigak-Tash coal mining project by gathering near the mine. Protesters expressed concern over an environmental impact of the coal mine on the local river and pice trees in the area. [size=about 200]

On 7 February 2020, about 10 employees of the youth sport school protested outside the Issyk-Kul regional administration's office in the town of Karakol against the planned closure of the school which will result in the loss of jobs for 60 employees. [size=about 10]

On 6 February 2020, about 33 quarantined Kyrgyz truckers protested at the Torugart border post on the Kyrgyzstan-China border against lack of food in the facility. Truckers demanded border service provide food which truckers will pay for. [size=about 33]

On 6 February 2020, 200-500 residents of the Naryn region gathered in the village of Kalinin which is part of Ak-Tal town to protest against the $280 million Chinese investor funded logistics hub project in the area. Protesters believe the land where Chinese funded project is planned to be built, will be transferred to China in the future in exchange for debt. [size=200-500]
On 6 February 2020, about 30 protesters demonstrated outside the White House in Bishkek city demanding their land plots in Voenno-Antonovka village of Sokuluk district legalized. [size=about 30]

On 30 January 2020, a group of villagers from Kok-Serek village near Tengi town in Ala-Buka district of Kyrgyzstan gathered to protest the Uzbek border guards after they attempted to install a water canal on the claimed Kyrgyz territory. The border guards stopped their work upon the protest. [size=no report]
On 30 January 2020, about 100 residents of At-Bashi district gathered in the town of At-Bashi in protest of the planned China-funded logistics hub in the area. [size=about 100]

On 29 January 2020, about 50 residents of Ak-Suu in Issyk-Kul region gathered at the town administration's office demanding the local authorities to speed up the land allocation process for housing purposes. [size=about 50]

On 29 January 2020, more than 5 rioters have attempted to disrupt an NGO meeting in Bishkek city, discussing the legislative bill targeting NGOs in Kyrgyzstan. A brawl took place between the NGO representatives in the meeting and the rioters after which some rioters broke into the roundtable to express their support for the bill. [size=more than 5]

On 28 January 2020, about 400 villagers protested outside the At-Bashi district administration's office in the town of At-Bashi against the planned Chinese funded logistical hub in the district. Protesters demanded the Kyrgyz authorities stop to China's involvement in the project. [size=about 400]

On 28 January 2020, about 10 residents of 218th locality in Osh city protested against lack of access to drinking water in the neighbourhood demanding the city authorities provide water supply to their households. [size=about 10]

On 27 January 2020, about 10 residents of a neighbourhood on Pishpek street in Bishkek city protested against bad roads in the residential area demanding the Mayor's Office fix the local infrastructure. [size=about 10]

On 22 January 2020, about 150 supporters of the imprisoned former lawmaker Sadyr Japarov demonstrated outside the district administration's office in Tup village of Issyk Kul region demanding release of former MP from prison. [size=about 150]

On 15 January 2020, about 50 protesters gathered in Batken town of Batken region with the release of four villagers from the town of Kok-Tash near the border with Tajikistan. The villagers were detained after violent conflict broke out near Kok-Tash village between Tajik and Kyrgyz villagers on 11 January. [size=about 50]

On 15 January 2020, about 100 activists protested outside the Kyrgyz parliament in Bishkek city demanding the release of four villagers from the town of Kok-Tash near the border with Tajikistan. Protesters declared their demands such as president to meet citizens from the bordering areas, release of the detained villagers, creation of community watch teams near the border and resignation of the Deputy Prime-Minister. [size=about 100]

On 14 January 2020, five people, parents of the children that attend daycare number 5 in Bishkek city protested at the Mayor's Office in the business district demanding dismissal of the daycare manager due to violations and stealing of food from the facility. [size=5]

On 14 January 2020, about 20 tenants of the newly-built apartment building on Motornaya street in Osh city protested outside their homes demanding their mortgage interest rates reduced or completely removed due to unsafe living conditions in the building which is becoming a financial burden because they are paying more out of their own pockets to fix the building. [size=about 20]

On 13 January 2020, about 10 former employees of the Kyrgyz National History Museum protested outside the museum in Bishkek city against illegal lay off accusing the new director of violating labour code and improper conduct. [size=about 10]

On 13 January 2020, about 15 demonstrators protested outside the Kyrgyz parliament demanding release of their four fellows that were arrested few days earlier near Kok-Tash village on the border with Tajikistan after riots between Kyrgyz and Tajik villagers. [size=about 15]

On 11 January 2020, rioters from Tajikistan threw stones at the vehicles belonging to Kyrgyz villagers in Tort-Kocho location near Kok-Tash village in Batken district that caused a verbal skirmish with the Kygryz villagers. Two groups then started to throw stoned to each other. Conflict was suppressed after intervention of the police and border services of the two countries . [size=unknown]

On 11 January 2020, Kyrgyz villagers blocked the Osh-Isfana-Batken motor road near Kok-Tash village in Batken district demanding release of their 6 fellow villagers from detention. 6 villagers were detained on 10 January for taking part in riots involving Tajik villagers. Road was reopened after police dispersed the protesters and unblock traffic. [size=unknown]

On 10 January 2020, around midnight, in the area of Zhaka-Oruk near Kok-Tash village, Batken district, unidentified people threw stones at a Kyrgyz car heading to Batken. These persons were then reported to have hid in Tajik side of the border. Kyrgyz authorities reported that there are injured citizens of Kyrgyzstan from among those who were in the car. The car has broken rear and side windows. Also, later in the same night, it was claimed that some Tajik citizens had stoned the house of a Kyrgyz citizen in the Dakhma area near same village. After these incident, Kyrgyz border guards later opened fire in the air near the border. No report of a confrontation or injuries from that fire. [size=unknown]
KFTU: Kyrgyzstan Federation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (Kyrgyzstan)
On 9 January, 15-20 KFTU members protested outside the Supreme Court in Bishkek city demanding resignation of the Union leader due to corruption allegations and abuse of office. [size=15-20]

On 9 January, a chief-editor of the anti-corruption website Factcheck was beaten up by 3 unknown attackers outside his office in Bishkek city. Factcheck was part of the recent investigative reporting by consortium of news organizations on massive corruption and money laundering schemes in Kyrgyzstan. [size=3]

On 9 January 2020, it was reported by Tajik authorities that some citizens of Kyrgyzstan attacked a citizen of Tajikistan, and broke a mirror of his car with a stone, in Jaka Oruk area, near the Tajik-Kyrgyz border close to the Kok-Tash village, Batken region [size=no report].

On 8 January, 15-20 residents of the village of Jatan gathered on the premises of the Chinese coal mining company project demanding complete shutdown of the coal mine. Protesters expressed concerns for the negative impact of the coal project on the environment. [size=15-20]
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On 6 January, Uzbek border guards shot fire in the air on the Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan border near Chon-Sai village in Ala-Buka district, after a brawl took place between the Kazakh villagers and Uzbek border guards when the Uzbek guards drove cattle into the lands where Kyrgyz villagers reportedly owned livestock. [size=unknown]

On 5 January, about 60 supporters of an imprisoned Kyrgyz politician gathered in Ton district of Issyk-Kul region demanding his release from prison. Protesters urged the country's president to listen to the people. [size=about 60]
On 3 January 2020, 5-10 residents of Jibek-Jolu village in Kara-Suu town vicinity of Naryn region protested demanding access to drinking water. [size=5-10]

On 27 December, about 20 residents of the town of Kok-Jangak protested against the local coal mine near the mining project. Protesters complained about the coal mine having a negative impact on the local environment. [size=about 20]

On 27 December 2019, the coordinator of a contemporary feminist art-exhibition in Bishkek city was attacked by two rioters near her home in the late night hours. The exhibtion had received a lot of reaction from anti-feminism groups in late-November. [size=2]

On 26 December 2019, 10-15 relatives and supporters of arrested Kyrgyz politician protested outside the main government building in Bishkek city demanding fair justice and his release from detention. He was detained on 12 December and charged with provoking the mass riots in 7-8 August at the former Kyrgyz president's mansion. [size=10-15]

On 24 December 2019, about 30 cargo truck drivers protested at the Ak-Tilek Avtodorozhny checkpoint near Hun Chi village in Ysyk-Ata district of Chui region against discrimination of Kyrgyz truck drivers by the Kazakh border authorities and imposing administrative barriers by the Kazakh Customs for transiting Kyrgyz cargo trucks through Kazakhstan. [size=about 30]

On 23 December 2019, dozens of truck drivers gathered outside the Kyrgyz government representative office in Talas city demanding intervention in their problems with the road police in Kazakhstan due to excessive fines for traffic violations. Kyrgyz authorities responded by intiating talks with the Kazakh countrparts through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. [size=dozens]

On 21 December 2019, 20-30 villagers in the town of Itagar gathered in the center of the village to protest against rising number of cattle theft in the area. Protesters expressed their dissatisfaction with the local authorities and police for being unable to curb the crime problem. [size=20-30]

On 19 December 2019, about 55 supporters of the former lawmaker Sadyr Japarov who is inprison, gathered at the Gorky square in Bishkek city wearing t-shirts with his image and placard for his release from jail. Former MP was sentenced to 11 years and 6 months in prison for organizing mass protests. [size=about 55]

On 19 December 2019, 15-20 protesters demonstrated outside the Supreme Court in Bishkek city demanding dismissal of the head of the Worker's Union in Kyrgyzstan. Protesters accused the head of union of misuse of funds and mismanagement of properties. [size=15-20]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force; Government of Kyrgyzstan (2017-)

On 18 December 2019, 6 Kyrgyz nationals, including 1 policeman and 1 local councilman were injured by the gunshots after violent riots between Kyrgyz and Tajik villagers in Kok-Tash village of Batken region bordering with Tajikistan. Shots were fired from the Tajik side and was related to the disputed borders between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. [size=unknown]

On 18 December 2019, about 600 protesters demonstrated in the Ala-Too main square in Bishkek in support of free speech and against corruption in the Kyrgyz state. Protest was sparked by Matrayimov family lawsuit against three news organizations that published investigative report on money laundering in Kyrgyzstan. [size=about 600]

On 16 December 2019, 30-40 Kyrgyz villagers from Kok-Tash town in Batken district protested against the fence that was being installed by the Tajik villagers. Kyrgyz Border Service officers who were called in to the scene ordered to halt any construction on the disputed territory which Tajik villagers refused to do so. No further information, no report of physical violence. [size=30-40]

On 16 December 2019, about 20 villagers in Kyzyl-Unkur village of Bazar-Korgon district protested against reappointment of the director of the local forest park. Villagers insisted he is unfit for the job due to his unprofessional conduct toward the local population. [size=about 20]

On 16 December 2019, about 20 residents of Toloikon village near Kara-Suu township in Osh region protested near their homes against road construction project on parts of their land demanding to stop the construction activity and accusing the local councilman of instigating a land dispute in the village. [size=about 20]

On 14 December, more than 20 students and their parents demonstrated outside a high school on Tokombayev street in Bishkek city against the replacement of the current school director with another. [size=more than 20]

On 13 December 2019, 30-40 relatives and friends of homicide victim protested outside the city court in Tokmok city demanding justice in the case after judge ruled to release suspect from detention. Protesters accused a judge of corruption and called for the Kyrgyz authorities to intervene in the case. [size=30-40]

On 12 December, about 100 activists and journalists came out to the main Ala-Too square in Bishkek city wearing respiratory masks in protest of deteriorating air pollution in the country's capital. [size=about 100]

On 12 December, about 50 retail shop owners protested at the Osh bazaar in Bishkek city in prolomged dispute with the market management that is planning to move retailers out of their current location. [size=about 50]

On 11 December, 10-15 residents of the Kulundu village in Leilek district of Batken region on the border with Tajikistan gathered to protest and express their frustrations with the government of Kyrgyzstan due to lack of social assistance and lack of electricity supply. Villagers told the local blogger the country's authorities aren't paying enough attention to the Kyrgyz communities in the bordering territory. [size=10-15]
On 7 December, about 100 Bishkek city residents including government officials took part in the march against domestic violence at the Yntymak park in Kyrgyzstan. [size=about 100]

On 5 December, dozens of residents of Chaek town gathered at the local administration in protest of a lack of access to drinking water in town. Protesters demanded the authorities resolve the issue in a timely manner. [size=dozens]

On 5 December 2019, about 15 protesters gathered outside the Pervomaisky district court in Bishkek in support of the online activist who manages a political news page on Facebook. He was detained on 24 November and accused of incitement of inter-regional tensions. Similarly, 20-30 supporters and relatives of former Kyrgyz officials gathered outside the Sverdlovsky district court in Bishkek demanding a fair trial for a number of high-ranking officials including 2 former prime-ministers. The officials were arrested and charged with corruption in the China-funded power-heating plant modernization project. [size=35-45]

On 3 December, about 20 protesters staged a rally outside the Kyrgyz parliament in Bishkek city demanding reforms of the coutnry's judiciary. Protesters called for the authorities to eradicate corruption in the courts and remove corrupt judges. [size=about 20]

On 2 December, a group of conservative activists protested at the Ministry of Culture, Information and Tourism against the feminist art exhibition including images of naked women. Protesters demanded resignation of the museum director where exhibition was organized the and cancellation of the exhibition. [size=no report]

On 2 December, an unknown number of villagers in the town of Itagar gathered at the local township administration demanding the police to find the criminals that stole sheep from the village. [size=unknown]

On 1 December, 10-15 protesters demonstrated outside the presidential administration in Bishkek demanding the issue of water supply resolved in the outer city neighborhoods. Protesters complained their calls were ignored by the Kyrgyz authorities for a number of years. [size=10-15]

On 29 November, about 300 residents of Naryn city gathered at the local Youth palace in protest against the electricity tariff demanding lowering the rate. Residents urged the Kyrgyz authorities to remove exisiting high rates for locals that use up to 3000 kvt/hour during winter season. [size=about 300]

On 29 November 2019, residents of a newly constructed neighbourhood at the outskirts of Bishkek organized a protest after they received a notice that a minibus line which was taking them to the city would be abolished. [size=no report]
Military Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) National Guard
Military Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) National Guard
On 28 November 2019, a unit commander of the National Guard platoon assaulted a subordinate serviceman with a baton while on duty at the presidential residency in Ala-Archa locality of Bishkek city.

On 25 November, about 1000 protesters demonstrated at the Alatoo main square in Bishkek against the corruption in the country's Customs agency. Massive protest was triggered after joint investigative report from RFERL and OCCRP on the Uighur businessman's assassination in Istanbul on 10 November and its link to the 700 million dollar worth money laundering scheme involving Kyrgyz Customs former officials. [size=about 1000]
On 25 November, 5-10 residents of Karakol city gathered at the local stadium in protest against the corruption in Kyrgyzstan. Protesters demanded eradication of corruption in the country. [size=5-10]

On 24 November 2019, about 100 protesters rallied at the Bereket pavilion of Osh bazaar in Bishkek city which has had fire incidents on two occasions previously. The district authorities reported that the gathering occurred due to the distribution of spots in the newly rebuilt market. [size=about 100]
On 22 November 2019, a group of Hepatitis B patients organized a protest in Bishkek and demanded from the government to introduce national vaccination for the disease. [size=no report]

On 19 November, about 10 car drivers staged an auto protest in Balykchy city against high traffic violation fines in Kyrgyzstan. Drivers urged the Kyrgyz authorities to reduce fines and increase wages for road policemen to eliminate corruption and bribery among the policemen. [size=about10]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-); Government of Kyrgyzstan (2017-)

On 16 November, about 30 activists, UN volunteers, some government workers and Bishkek city police officials organized a march near Alatoo square dedicated to the victim of road accidents in Kyrgyzstan. Organizers said 2-3 people die on the country's roads every day. [size=about30]

On 15 November, 15-20 protesters gathered in the village of Uchkun expressing their protest with the local authorities due to long disputed land property rights. Representative of the district adminsitration told protesters their land purchase transactions have been annuled because of the corruption which has taken place in their cases. [size=15-20]

On 12 November, about 15 protesters demonstrated outside the presidential administration in Bishkek demanding justice in a murder case. Protesters urged the authorities to dismiss the judge who ruled on the case and bring back perpetrators of the crime to justice. [size=about15]

On 11 November, 10-15 protesters demonstrated outside the Kemin district court in Chuy region demanding justice for an assaulted and raped woman. Protesters accused the court of corruption and letting rape suspect walk free without facing justice. [size=10-15]

On 11 November, a group of protesters gathered outside the presidential administration in Bishkek rallying against the corruption and rule of oligarchs in Kyrgyzstan. Protesters demanded dismissal of 6000 officials in the country who are accused of being corrupt. [size=no report]

On 6 November, a group of protesters demonstrated outside the main government office in Bishkek city demanding resignation of a Kyrgyz lawmaker. Protesters criticized MP for supporting school funding by the parents of the students in Kyrgyzstan. [size=noreport]

On 4 November, 5-10 protesters demonstrated against high traffic violation fines at the intersection of Chuy-Auezova streets in Bishkek city. Protesters demanded the Kyrgyz government revise fines and apply traffic fines equally on officials that break traffic rules. [size=5-10]

On 31 October, about 40 protesters gathered outside the Kyrgyz parliament in Bishkek calling for lawmakers to get involved in their legal issues regarding land ownership. Protesters urged the country's parliament to resolve their land rights problems. [size=about 40]

On 30 October, about 10 protesters rallied outside the Kyrgyz parliament in Bishkek expressing concern with the country's Prosecutor General's Office performance in the cases of land and property ownership disputes. Protesters urged the authorities to create better oversight. [size=about 10]

On 26 October, villagers in the village Ak-Tatyr bordering Batken province with Tajikistan blocked the inter-state road demanding their fellow villagers to be released by the Tajikistan authorities who had been detained two days earlier. Road block was removed after negotiation with the Kyrgyz police the same day. [size=no report]

On 25 October, 50 villagers of Kyzyl-Tuu protested against the waste dump near their town demanding the local administration to fix the problem. Protesters wanted the dump to be completely removed from the area. [size=50]
On 25 October, 15-20 villagers of Dachnoye protested against the recycling facility in their area. Protesters demanded the local administration to remove the facility from the area. [size=15-20]

On 24 October, around 100 protesters gathered in Osh city main square to rally against the mining project. Protesters demanded police to release two of their fellow villagers and stop the mining project operation. [size=around 100]

On 23 October, 15-20 supporters of a Tengri spiritual leader demanded the authorities to stop the persecution of their leader. They urged the government to register the religion of Tengri in the country. [size=15-20]

On 22 October, about 500 local residents demanded an access to the state reserved nature area and protested against the local authorities ban on entering the reserved area for collecting walnuts. District chief informed the crowd that the issue would be discussed in the country's parliament until further notice. [size=about 500]

On 19 October, about 50 supporters and relatives of the ex-president's bodyguard protested against his persecution in Bishkek. Protesters demanded fair investigation of his case by the Kyrgyz authorities. [size=about 50]

On 19 October 2019, a group of Kyrgyz villagers protested on the main road in Zhaka-Oruk neighborhood near Ak-Sai village in Batken region demanding Tajik counterparts remove road bumps they have installed previously. Protesters called for the Kyrgyz officials to get involved in conflict resolution between Kyrgyz and Tajik villagers. [size=no report]

On 17 October, about 100 protesters demonstrated against the pressure from local authorities that impeded the local concrete plant's operations in Jalal-Abad. Protesters urged the authorities to let the plant continue its business without the government's interference. [size=about 100]
On 15 October, about 100 protesters demanded land plots for housing from the city administration in Bishkek. Police detained 5 protesters after illegal attempts to cease land. [size=about 100]

On 15 October, about 60 employees of the state building department protested against their leadership due to bribery and corruption in the organization in Kara-Suu. Protesters urged the Kyrgyz authorities investigate corruption in the organization. [size=about 60]

On 14 October, 30 airport security workers protested against mass lay off demanding their jobs back in Dacha-Suu. Airport management denied there is a lay off claiming that it is an internal reorganization. [size=30]

On 14 October, 15-20 supporters of a political activist rallied in Bishkek outside the parliament calling for resignation of the Kyrgyz President. Protesters urged the country's leader to step down over inability to govern. [size=15-20]

On 11 October 2019, more than several relatives of the deceased victim rioted at the Chui regional court in Bishkek city throwing bottles at a judge demanding he speaks to them to explain the reasons for acquittal of suspects in the homicide case resulting in death of their family member. Policemen were forced to intervene to protect a judge from rioters outside the court as judge was leaving the scene in his personal automobile. [size=more than several]

Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On 10 October, border troops of Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan conducted a military drill in the bordering district in Ferghana Valley. It was designed to improve coordination between the states in the scenario of 'terrorist' activity near frontier areas.

On 7 October, 3 employees of the nursing home in Bishkek protested against corruption in their work place outside the city administration. Protesters demanded the authorities to investigate the nursing home management for embezzlement. [size=3]
On 7 October, 50-100 protesters demonstrated in Bishkek against the legislative bill on unions in Kyrgyzstan. Protesters rejected the bill demanding revision of its current version. [size=50-100]

On 6 October, about 500 local residents protested in Kyzyl-Ozgarysh against the mining exploration activity in the area. Protesters demanded halt to all mining activity and cancel the company's license. [size=about 500]

On 2 October, 10 protesters gathered outside the presidential administration to rally against the widespread practice of collecting payments from parents in schools. Protesters demanded the government to modify existing laws on education. [size=10]

On 1 October, about 100 senior citizen demonstrators organized a Nordic Walk in Bishkek to raise awareness on aging and retirement. Demonstrators put up banners against any form of discrimination toward senior citizens based on their age. [size=about 100]
Labour Group (Kyrgyzstan); KFTU: Kyrgyzstan Federation of Trade Unions

On 30 September, The Federation of Unions organized a protest in Bishkek against a bill in the parliament. Protesters insist current legislation contradicts international norms of labor. [size=no report]

On 30 September, about 60 protesters gathered in Ak-Dobo to protest against an arrest of ex-president's bodyguard. Protesters urged the incumbent president to oversee a fair investigation of the case involving bodyguard. [size=about 60]

On 28 September, residents of Chaldovar clashed with law enforcers. Reportedly the policemen tried to detain a local border guard over alleged bribing, but the locals spontaneously defended him with stones in their hands. In self-defense, policemen fired several warning shots into the air. As a result, several policemen received minor injuries. [size=no report]

On 28 September, a crew of the RFE/RL were approached by unknown individuals during their work in Osh. These people, reportedly associated with the former politician (the subject of journalist's work), attacked them, seized their equipment including a mobile phone, a drone and cameras. The damaged equipment was later returned by law enforcers.

On 28 September, a fight broke between 25 local residents and workers of the marble company. Residents damaged company vehicles, equipment and set company's tent on fire which resulted in an explosion of a propane tank. Rioters blamed the company for altering the local river's flow through the village. 3 people received injuries. [size=at least 25]

On 27 September 2019, more than several villagers of Chong-Alai district rioted at a mining project managed by a Chinese firm, near the village of Daroot-Korgon. They demanded an explanation from the Chinese nationals regarding an earlier incident where a Chinese miner allegedly threatened a Kyrgyz man with a knife. Rioters blocked the Chinese workers' vehicle at the project demanding them to come out. [size=more than several]

On 25 September, traders from the local bazaar in Osh gathered near the city hall of the capital Bishkek, demanding solution of various economic challenges related to their trade. Reportedly over 250 traders participated. The authorities promised to find a solution and the crowd dispersed. [size=over 250]
On 25 September, residents of Bishkek gathered in the city center, demanding more efficient protection of climate and natural environment. Reportedly seven activists participated. [size=7]

On 23 September, about a dozen of residents of Arashan gathered for a rally. They complained that in connection to their recent collective appeal to the prosecutor, who investigates the events in Koy-Tash (the arrest of the ex-President Atambayev), many local residents are frequently taken for interrogations, even the sick, elderly or mothers with babies. [size=about a dozen]

On 20 September, the organizer of the planned march for the protection of climate cancelled the rally, that was planned to be held in the upcoming day in Bishkek. Allegedly she was threatened by law enforcers not to realize the event, since, according to them, various groups related to 'feminism' or 'LGBT' may join the event for self-promotion.

On 17 September, about 15 protesters gathered in Bishkek, outraged by the armed clash in Batken region. Law enforcers called the rally unauthorized and briefly detained about 10 of them and took them away. [size=about 15]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 16 September 2019, 1 Kyrgyz border guard and 3 Tajik border troops were killed in a firefight between the Kyrgyz and Tajik border forces at the Maksat border post near Kulundu village in Leilek district of Batken region. The armed clash was triggered after construction activity by the Tajik villagers on the disputed territory, which the Kyrgyz residents responded to with their own construction nearby.

On 14 September, about 50 protesters gathered in Ak-Sai village, Batken region, expressing their outrage related to the rising tensions on the border with Tajikistan and allegedly illegal construction works conducted by Tajiks in the disputed area. [size=about 50]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 13 September, dozens of protesters affiliated to the SDPK party gathered near the office of the prosecutor in Bishkek. The meeting was related to the recent administrative seizure of the Forum building, where the party officially resides, and to the seizure of laptops and documents related to its internal administration. [size=dozens]

On 13 September, protesters gathered in Malovodnoye, Kyrgyzstan. They were predominantly parents of local schoolchildren, outraged by economic condition and management of the school fund. The exact number of protesters was not reported. [size=no report]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

As reported on 12 September, law enforcers effectively interrupted work of the SDPK party by blocking the Forum building in Bishkek, where their offices are located, and seizing laptops and many relevant documents from them. Several members went to complain and request for an explanation to a prosecutor but left without a respond. Authorities claim that the building was blocked as a subject of the ongoing investigation of the former President Atambayev.

On 12 September, the government of Kyrgyzstan confirmed a successful agreement with the government of Uzbekistan on cross-border land exchange. According to the agreement, Uzbekistan is given over 40 ha of land near the Kerkidan reservoir in the Aravan district of the Osh region and Kyrgyzstan is given a similar area near the village of Gulbaar in the same district.

On 11 September, residents of Kerkidan settlement, Aravan district gathered again near the Kerkidan reservoir, demanding the Uzbek armed forces, standing on the other side of the disputed border, to leave the area. Reportedly about 30 protesters gathered. [size=about 30]

On 10 September, about 50 residents of Kerkidan settlement, Aravan district gathered near the Kerkidan reservoir, outraged by the fact that Uzbek military forces erected fences on their side of the border. Somewhat later, representatives and law enforcers of Kyrgyzstan arrived and arranged a compromise with the Uzbeks. Neither injuries nor direct involvement of the Uzbeks in the protest were reported. [size=about 50]

On 9 September, residents of Tup gathered near the building of the local administration. They complained about alleged inefficiency of the officials and demanded higher transparency and responsibility of their work. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 5 September, about 100 residents of Ak-Talaa district gathered to express their discontent with the ongoing construction works in the district and demanded a meeting with the government. [size=about 100]

On 5 September, relatives and friends of the victims of the recent fight in Bishkek gathered in the city center, demanding proper investigation of the incident, which had taken place in late August and where reportedly a law enforcer intentionally let one perpetrator escape the scene. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2019, several residents of the Issyk-Kul region protested near Balykshy town against the Tash-Bulak uranium mining project demanding the interagency commission members that have conducted an environmental research into the project's impact remain impartial. [size=several]

On 3 September 2019, hundreds of retail shop owners protested at the Bereket company owned pavilion in Osh bazaat in Bishkek city demanding the city administration intervenes in their dispute with the company and retains its ownership of the pavilion to keep it under control of the city authorities. Protesters demanded the city provides electricity to their businesses after Bereket cut power supply over dispute. [size=hundreds]

On 3 September 2019, about 20 Tajik villagers protested in the bordering village of Orto-Boz near Ak-Tatyr demanding the Kyrgyz villager remove his car from the disputed land where he set up a shop to sell goods out of his car. Kyrgyz villagers responded by insisting that the land was leased for 49 years by the Kyrgyz side and it was legal to do business on the disputed territory. [size=about 20]

On 3 September, female protesters gathered in Bishkek, they were covered in the funeral outfit. They said that due to alleged unjust decisions of Kyrgyz courts over their family members, they already felt like living corpses. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. [size=no report]
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 2 September, a conflict occurred between Tajik border guards and Kyrgyz local residents near Ak-Sai village, Batken district. Reportedly, Kyrgyz nationals were collecting stones from a local river (disputed territory) and the Tajiks tried to stop them by firing warning shots into the air from the other bank of the river. No injuries were reported.
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 31 August 2019, a riot between Tajik and Kyrgyz villagers broke out involving Kyrgyz border guards when dozens of Tajik villagers launched a road construction project on the disputed border land between Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. Tajik rioters threw stones at the Kyrgyz border guards after which border patrol fired warning shots. [size=dozens]

On 29 August, around 100 supporters of an imprisoned politician from the Ata Meken political party and former government officials gathered near a court in Bishkek. They wanted to attend their hearing at a court, but the process was declared close and they were not allowed to enter the building. [size=around 100]

On 26 August, an elderly resident of the Ak-Suu district was reportedly attacked and beaten by a law enforcer. Furthermore, the policeman also demanded that the victim should not be treated in a hospital.
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 24 August, a conflict occurred on the border of Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. Reportedly about 15-20 Tajiks started to destroy a fence of a Kyrgyz resident of the village Zhany-Zher and attacked the other Kyrgyz residents. Then the Kyrgyz border guards arrived and the Tajiks reportedly attacked them with stones. When the law enforcers started firing several warning shots into the air, they escaped to the Tajik territory. Two guards were injured during the incident. [size=about 15-20]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan; Former Government of Kyrgyzstan (2017-)

Since 22 August, several political supporters and allies of the former President of Kyrgyzstan Almazbek Atambayev have been arrested, put under house arrest or summoned by law enforcers across the country in relation to various alleged crimes of Atambayev himself or the recent riots in Koy-Tash. The charges are e.g. hostage-taking or high-profile corruption. These arrests are perceived as a sign of a significant ongoing political shift in the whole country. [coded to Bishkek]

On 22 August, the government of Kyrgyzstan passed a special law on protecting women from abuse during emergency or crisis situations. According to the law, various specific institutions and bodies are responsible to prevent gender-based violence of the more vulnerable part of the population.

On 9 August 2019, about 15 residents of Bayish village near Jany-Bazar township in Nookat district of Osh region protested near their homes against the transfer of nearby land to the private companies, which would build asphalt mixing plant, and demanded from the local authorities to reverse their decision. Protesters complained such project would have a negative environmental impact on the village. [size=about 15]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security

On 9 August, 15 police officers entered the Media Forum building in Bishkek, which housed the April-TV news agency owned by ex-President Atambayev, who had been arrested the day before. They ordered all staff to leave and seized the property, sealing the entrance and blocking further broadcasting. The SDPK headquarters was also located there and similarly sealed off as a result. Authorities stated it was one of the measures taken to freeze Atambayev assets.

On 8 August, another clash erupted over the demolition of the 'Elephants' children's park in Bishkek, when local residents including women went to the streets and attempted to remove the fencing of the construction site. Private security guards responded by beating several of the rioters, injuring several elderly people. [size=no report]
On 8 August, a protest was held in front of the courthouse in Osh in support of the man suspected for murdering the prosecutor of Batken region. [size=no report]

On 8 August, riots broke out in the main square in Bishkek after the arrest of ex-President Atambayev earlier in the evening. Around 1500 supporters of Atambayev damaged buildings, threw stones and erected barricades throughout the night. They also attacked and threw stones at journalists. Police forces dispersed the rioters with stun grenades, detaining 40 and injuring several others. [size=around 1500]

On 8 August, in the morning after the failed attempt to arrest ex-President Atambayev, around 500 of his supporters gathered in Kok-Jar on the road to Atambayev's compound and blocked a second attempt of police forces to arrest him by throwing stones at them. A larger police operation commenced later this day. [size=around 500]
