On 8 August, a third attempt was made by special forces to detain ex-President Atambayev after two failed attempts. At least three thousand police forces blocked all roads to Koy-Tash and jammed communication networks. They clashed with Atambayev supporters who erected burning barricades and threw stones during a two-hour confrontation, while police used tear gas and stun grenades to disperse them. After a negotiation Atambayev surrendered to the police later that evening. He was arrested and charged with corruption, hostage-taking and violent resistance. He was later accused of plotting a coup. A total of 170 people were injured over the two days of clashes, including 79 police officers.

On 7 August, a clash erupted between local residents including women and security guards of a construction company over the demolition of the 'Elephants' children's park in Bishkek. Several rioters engaged in a brawl, threw stones at the representatives of the security company and tried to tear down fences, in an attempt to stop the demolition of the iconic statues in the park to make way for luxury apartments. Minor injuries were reported. [size=no report]

On 7 August 2019, about 200 residents of Naryn region gathered close to the village of Kara-Chiy near Solton-Sary gold project demanding all mining activity by the Chinese state affiliated company halted and mining equipment removed from the mine. [size=about 200]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security
24Kg; AP; BBC News; RFE/RL; Kaktus Media; Vecherniy Bishkek; AKIpress; AFP; Eurasianet; Kloop; Vesti.kg

On 7 August, the GKNB special forces stormed the residence of ex-President Almazbek Atambayev in the village of Koi-Tash in order to arrest him on corruption charges. They entered the fortified compound firing rubber bullets and tear gas grenades, but were forced to retreat when a large group of Atambayev's supporters attacked them. One sniper reportedly killed the deputy commander of the special forces from inside the compound. At least 6 reps of the special forces were taken hostage after the attack and were held throughout the night. 80 people were injured during the clash, including 15 police officers. An investigation later held a single armed gunman responsible for the death of the police officer, whereas other supporters were reported to be unarmed. Atambayev's immunity had previously been withheld and he had refused to comply with two subpoenas.

On 6 August, about 600-700 local residents held a protest at the Chinese-owned goldmine at Solton-Sary, a day after riots had injured 20 Chinese miners. They set up a camp of yurts near the highway and continued to demand the suspension of the mine. The peaceful protest was attended by several government representatives who engaged in negotiations. The protesters stayed there for several days until the camp was disbanded. [size=about 600-700]
On 5 August, over 60 people held a protest in Manas district of Talas region. [coded to Talas] [size=over 60]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 5 August, a verbal altercation erupted between 10-15 residents of the Tajik village of Ovchi Kalacha, B. Ghafurov district, and Kyrgyz border guards at the Kyrgyz village of Maksat, Leilek district. A disagreement erupted after Tajik villagers wanted to use a football field on disputed territory for Eid celebrations, but were stopped from doing so by Kyrgyz border guards. An earlier clash about the football field had occurred a year before.

On 5 August 2019, about 50 drivers of the municipal bus company protested at the bus depot in Osh city against raising transit fees for passengers which protesters argued is not helping them to fill their daily fee quotas. Protesters complained they are not willing to work if their wages directly depend on quota-based performance. [size=about 50]

On 5 August, a clash erupted between around 300 local residents and Chinese workers of a gold mine in Solton-Sary, Naryn region. Local residents had come to demand the suspension of mining in the region, when both parties started throwing stones at each other. 20 employees of the gold mine were injured and hospitalized, 19 of whom were Chinese gold miners. The mine was suspended a few days later. Local residents had expressed their anger in several demonstrations in the days before, after the mass deaths of livestock in the region. [size=around 300]

On 4 August, around 30 local livestock breeders held a protest at a Chinese goldmine in Solton-Sary, demanding punishment for those who fought with two local residents the day before. They believed the Chinese workers had provoked the conflict. [size=around 30]

In the night of 2 to 3 August, a verbal altercation ended in a fight between two local residents of Solton-Sary and several Chinese gold miners. Two Kyrgyz men were injured and hospitalized. Tensions had been high between residents and employees of the Chinese goldmine after the mass death of livestock in the region, associated in the opinion of local residents with the mining activities. [size=no report]

On 31 July, several people held a protest in Bishkek in support of the Khachaturian sisters - three girls in Moscow who had killed their father after years of abuse. Their case sparked protests across Russia. During the protest, police seized a phone of a Kloop journalist. [size=several]
Former Government of Kyrgyzstan (2017-); SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 29 July, supporters of the detained former prime minister held a protest in Kochkor to demand his release. The protest was attended by members of the Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan. The politician had been detained earlier for corruption charges, which his supporters saw as an act of political repression by the new President. [size=no report]
On 26 July, about 40 residents of Bishkek gathered near the building of the local administration, protesting against alleged inefficiency of the public transport system. [size=about 40]

On 24 July, 4 police officers were wounded in a clash with villagers of Ak-Sai when they tried to return order by stopping them from once again blocking the road connecting the Tajik exclave of Vorukh to Tajikistan, which had caused violent clashes in the two days before. Police used sound grenades to disperse the crowd. No injuries among the villagers were reported. [size=no report]

On 24 July 2019, 10-15 women from Ak-Sai village protested outside the regional administration's office in Batken township against the use of riot police force to suppress demonstration in Ak-Sai village on the same day demanding officials come out and explain reasons behind the deployment of police units against villagers. [size=10-15]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 23 July, 17 Kyrgyz were injured, including 4 residents of Ak-Sai village and 13 border guards, by Tajik residents of the Vorukh exclave who threw stones and fired rifles at them. The clash followed one day after tensions had erupted between the two communities over the construction of a road through Kyrgyz territory. More villagers were evacuated from Ak-Sai that evening reaching a total of 600. [size=no report]

On 22 July, one Tajik man was killed and 15 others were wounded during cross-border clashes between Tajik and Kyrgyz residents of Ak-Sai village and the Vorukh exclave. Clashes erupted over the construction of a road connecting the exclave to Tajikistan, angering Kyrgyz villagers who responded by blocking the road. Kyrgyz reportedly used hunting rifles while Tajiks threw stones. Border guards intervened to restore peace. 150 Kyrgyz villagers were evacuated later that evening from Ak-Sai and given food and shelter. [size=no report]
On 21 July, several people held a protest against the poor conditions and state of disrepair of the gardens outside of the botanical gardens in Bishkek. [size=several]

On 18 July, large-scale exercises of the military forces of Kyrgyzstan, the National Guard and several governmental agencies were held in the Sary-Tash district. The aim of the exercise was to tackle an armed group of enemies on the Kyrgyz territory. About 600 soldiers and various military equipment including helicopters and artillery were involved.

On 17 July, around 100 local residents held a protest at a Chinese-run gold mine in Solton-Sary, Naryn region, in order to demand the suspension of mining in the region. The protesters expressed their fears of environmental pollution after the mass deaths of livestock in the region. [size=around 100]
On 16 July, supporters of one of the ex-MPs held a rally in front of the Supreme Court in Bishkek. [size=no report]
On 16 July, over 20 people held a protest in front of the parliament building in Bishkek to demand the return of their land plots in Lesnoe village. [size=over 20]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 16 July 2019, dozens of supporters of former Prime-Minister Sapar Isakov gathered in the village of Kochkor of Naryn region in protest of his detention and to announce a creation of the campaign in defense of detained former PM who was under criminal investigation in corruption case. [size=dozens]

On 15 July, about 200 residents of nearby villages held a protest in front of the court and the police station in Tokmok against the unfair persecution of local youth. They protested after a man who had taken part in a fight was not persecuted due to an alleged protection of a local member of parliament. [size=about 200]

On 15 July 2019, about 6 activists protested in the Maxim Gorky park in Bishkek city against the regional court's ruling to dismiss charges against suspects in rape case from 2013. Protesters demanded the Kyrgyz authorities revise the court ruling and bring the rape perpetrators to justice. [size=about 6]

On 15 July, around 70 people held a protest in front of the government administration in Naryn against Chinese gold mining activities in Solton-Sary. The protesters expressed their fears of environmental pollution after the mass deaths of livestock in the region. [size=around 70]

On 13 July 2019, about 20 residents of Tup district in Issyk-Kul region gathered at the Karkyra summer pasture calling for the country's president to revise imprisoned Kyrgyz politician Sadyr Japarov's case demanding his release from prison. [size=about 20]
On 10 July, a protest was held by women in front of the Supreme Court in Bishkek in support of the woman who had been gang-raped in Talas. [size=no report]

On 10 July, two families in Iskrinsk district, Chui region, fought over access to drinking water. Three people were hospitalized. Some sources reported the clash as an episode of ethnic conflict, however, others denied this. The village has a large Dungan minority and a history of ethnic conflict between Dungans and Kyrgyz. [size=no report]

On 3 July, several Tajik residents of Vorukh beat a Kyrgyz man who was selling petrol in the outskirts of Ak-Sai village across the border between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. He was hospitalized with a head injury. Tensions between Kyrgyz and Tajiks have been high since a road was constructed that cut off the Tajik exclave from mainland Tajikistan. [size=no report]

On 3 July, former President of Kyrgyzstan Atambayev and around 1000 of his supporters held a protest in front of the 'Media Forum' in Bishkek against the government of President Sooronbay Jeenbekov. The protest followed after Jeenbekov had withdrawn immunity status for Atambayev, opening the way for the former President to be persecuted for abuse of power and corruption. [size=around 1000]
On 2 July, 8 women held a protest in front of the Supreme Court in Bishkek in support of a woman gang-raped in Talas. [size=8]

On 27 June, the parliament deprived the immunity status from ex-President Almazbek Atambayev, which allowed law enforcement agencies to prosecute him for corruption. Atambayev believed that this decision was politically motivated by the current President. In response, Atambayev fortified his compound in Koi-Tash and gathered supporters, in order to put up resistance when the authorities try to forcefully arrest him.
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 26 June, supporters of the former President of Kyrgyzstan Atambayev (SDPK) held another rally in his residence in Koi-Tash. They declared their support to him and all accusations of corruption as illegitimate. Several hundreds of protesters reportedly participated. [Size=several hundreds]
On 26 June 2019, dozens of protesters demonstrated outside the Prosecutor General's Office in Bishkek city demanding justice for a victim of property scam which left her homeless. [size=dozens]

On 25 June, supporters of the former President of Kyrgyzstan Atambayev (SDPK) founded a 'National headquarters against lawlessness' in Atambayev's residence in Koi-Tash. Reportedly they decided to stay in the villa to guard him personally. Among others, a group of horsemen arrived and several yurts were erected to accommodate them.

On 25 June, around 50 protesters gathered in Bishkek with pickets, calling authorities to refund money they had previously invested in land plots. No intervention of law enforcers was reported. [size=around 50]

On 25 June 2019, about 30 protesters demonstrated at a peaceful rally in support of labour migrants which was organized in Bishkek by the Zamandash party. Protesters called for better working conditions and insurance for workers. [size=about 30]

On 24 June, members of the trade union federation, various other institutions and students gathered in Bishkek, protesting against adoption of a proposed law on trade unions. Around 100 individuals gathered. [size=around 100]

On 24 June, the leader of Hizb ut-Tahrir in Kyrgyzstan was arrested by 'anti-terrorist' police units in Jalal-Abad. The leader is wanted for spreading radicalizing materials and recruiting fighters. Hizb ut-Tahrir is designated a 'terrorist' organization in Kyrgyzstan.

On 23 June, an elderly woman was beaten by a Colonel of the Police Academy in Bishkek. She suffered severe bruises in her face. The police did not respond when she called the police. [coded according to the civilian's version]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 22 June, supporters of the former President of Kyrgyzstan Atambayev (SDPK party) gathered in his residence in Koi-Tash. They declared their support to him and all accusations of corruption as illegitimate. Reportedly around 300 of protesters gathered. [size=around 300)

On 22 June, young local residents of Bishkek held a public flash mob, theatrical performance and art exhibition. The aim was to raise awareness about violence against women, especially bride kidnapping, early marriages and limited education provided. [size=no report]

On 19 June 2019, more than several residents of the Pervoe Maya village in Sokuluk district were detained by police for protesting against the local mine which protesters have been resisiting due to environmental concerns. [size=more than several]

On 19 June 2019, more than 100 landowners in village Voenno-Antonovka in Sokuluk region organized a protest. They protested as they have no right to construct houses on the lands they own because of the lands' agricultural status. [size=more than 100]

On 18 June 2019, about 20 residents of Ketmen-Tobo village in Jalal-Abad region protested near their village administration against lack of attention from the district officials to their concerns regarding social grievances and water supply issues which protesters complained have been raised repeatedly by them but without success. [size=about 20]
On 17 June, members of the trade union federation gathered in Bishkek, protesting against adoption of a proposed law on trade unions. The exact number of protesters was not revealed.[size=no report]

On 17 June 2019, about 30 residents of Jiyde village in Suzak district of Jalal-Abad region protested against the Kyrgyz border post commander whom protesters accused of extorting bribes in exchange OF access to the gravel yard on the dry bed of bordering Karadarya river. Protesters demanded the local authorities intervene in their conflict with the border guards and ensure their way of make a living by collecting gravel. [size=about 30]

On 9 June, about 30 residents of Ak-Suu reportedly attacked a couple because of conflicts on using water in summer months. Among the attackers there were reportedly also a member of local administration and his family. [size=about 30]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 8 June, the SDPK party organized a rally in Bishkek. Protesters claimed that the current fight against corruption led by the government is selective and targeted against the former President Atambayev and his allies; Atambayev himself delivered a speech at the rally. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 7 June 2019, about 40 residents of Dachnoe village in Ysyk-Ata district of Chui region protested outside the local recycling facility demanding shut down of the operation due to negative environmental impact on the village. [size=about 40]

On 6 June, residents of Orok gathered again, following violent clashes in the previous day, predominantly supporting one of the group involved. Law enforcers were present and prevented a clash among the participants and detained a local administration official, suspected of organizing and provocation the previous clashes. On 6 June, several members of the SDPK party organized a flash mob in Bishkek, encouraging people to participate at the upcoming rally against corruption. Law enforcers approached, took their posters and took one member of the group to the police station for explanation. Later he was released. [size=several]

On 6 June 2019, about 15 activists and journalists protested at the Chui regional administration's office in the village of Lebedinovka outside Bishkek city demanding governor of Chui region resign from office and apologize to a female journalist for inappropriate comment regarding her appearance which he made a day earlier. On 5 June, a skirmish among three teenagers resulted in mob violence among two groups of residents of the Orok municipality. The clash was reportedly fought between two ethnic groups, as one of the participants was a Turk and the others Kyrgyz. Several houses were damaged. Law enforcers intervened and 31 individuals were detained, 24 of whom were released after questioning. [size=no report]

On 4 June, residents of Andarak village, Leilek district gathered for a rally and blocked a local road. They were protesting against alleged misuse of forest land in a disputed area nearby. Reportedly, around 60 protesters gathered. [size=around 60]

On 4 June 2019, residents of multistore building organized a protest in Bishkek against the contruction of a building that is allegedly too close their house, demanding the government demolishing the building. [size=no report]

On 3 June, supporters of opposition politician gathered outside the Bishkek police department building, opposing her detention and claiming it political. Reportedly around 40 protesters gathered. [size=around 40]

On 3 June, a 15-year old boy was detained by the police in Osh who put a bag over his head and choked him in order to make him confess to committing a theft. Medical examination later revealed injuries.

As reported on 3 June, around 20 residents of Zhiyde together complained about alleged harassment and money exertion by a commander of a local border post; some of them even claimed being repeatedly illegally detained and beaten by him in order to provide money.

On 3 June 2019, 30-40 residents of Kojo-Kelen village near the town of Papan in Kara-Suu district of Osh region protested against the imam of the local mosque demanding his resignation due to alleged assault records with his involvement. [size=30-40]

On 3 June, Kyrgyz residents of Iskra settlement, Leylek district gathered and blocked a local road; Tajik civilians were present as well. They demanded to tear down a house, which was reportedly being under construction illegally by Tajiks. Law enforcers came into place with local administration to calm the situation. No detentions reported. Exact number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 31 May 2019, 15-20 garage owners from Dzhal neighborhood protested outside the Mayor's Office in Bishkek city against takeover of their properties by the private company which restricted access to protesters. On 31 May, a resident of Bishkek was detained and reportedly beaten in order to confess to an alleged crime. Medical examination confirmed the physical attack.
On 31 May 2019, residents of a dormitory in Bishkek organized a protest against the plans to evict them. [size=no report]

On 31 May, an incident occurred among Uzbek civilians and Kyrgyz border guards in the Toguz Bulak area of the Osh region. Two Uzbek cars ignored commands of Kyrgyz law enforcers to stop moving towards the border; after warning shots Kyrgyz started firing at wheels of the vehicles. On 30 May, about 40 protesters, predominantly single mothers and health workers gathered for a rally in the center of Bishkek, demanding proper housing and social support of single mothers and state employees, especially health workers employed at a local clinic. [size=about 40]
On 30 May, a female resident of Bishkek was detained and reportedly beaten in order to confess to an alleged crime. Medical examination confirmed the physical attack.

On 30 May 2019, 5-10 villagers of Jiyde township in Suzak district of Jalal-Abad region protested in the village against misconduct and extortion of bribes by the Kyrgyz border guards in exchange for accessing gravel yard on the dry riverbed. On 29 May 2019, trailer drivers in At-Bashi region organized a protest against raising tax fees. They claimed that the clients have found other routes to transport goods due to increased taxes. Drivers from Issyk-Kul region joined the protest. [size=no report]

On 27 May, a rally was held in Bishkek, commemorating victims of bride kidnapping and violence, especially a woman killed by her lover right in a police cell. The organizers aimed to draw attention to the persisting problem. The number of protesters was not reported. [size=no report]

On 27 May, about 100 supporters of the former bodyguard of the President Atambayev, gathered in the village Bokonbayevo, Ton district, protesting against his imprisonment, allegedly politically motivated. On 27 May, residents of Ak-Suu District gathered for a rally protesting against alleged illegal construction at local recreation center and other violations of law related to the facility, as well as being concerned by environmental issues. On 22 May 2019, 40-50 residents of Papan village in Kara-Suu district protested outside the local administration's office against the newly elected head of the township accusing him of corruption and demanded re-elections. [size=40-50]

On 21 May, doctors from Bishkek hospitals gathered for a rally, demanding higher wages. They claim that more money was promised by the government, but never realized. On 20 May, a conflict occurred in Kara-Bak, Batken region where unknown people damaged a Kyrgyz building, located only few meters from the provisional demarcation line of Tajik-claimed contested territory nearby. The Tajik border guard prevented the Kyrgyz people repairing it, until the Kyrgyz border guards arrived and resolved the conflict.

On 17 May 2019, about 25 residents of Esenbay village protested near the town of Kerkidan in Aravan district of Osh region against lack of drinking water supply and severe water shortage during the summer season demanding the local authorities fix the issue. [size=about 25]

On 16 May, about 200 supporters of the former bodyguard of Kyrgyzstan President, gathered in the village Bokonbayevo, Ton district, protesting against his imprisonment, allegedly politically motivated. He was sentenced to 5 years over corruption when was serving as the head of the State Security Service. [size=about 200]

On 14 May 2019, about 10 garage owners protested against demolition of their garages on Tugelbai Ata street in Bishkek city by the Mayor's Office to build a road. Protesters insisted demolition was illegal due to pending lawsuit to cancel the city administration's plan in the city court. [size=about 10]

On 13 May, journalists of RFE/RL and NUR TV were attacked by unidentified individuals in Osh, while preparing a report on local illegal gambling business. Several attackers were detained. Both journalists did not report highly serious injuries, only scratches and damaged property. [size=no report]

On 13 May, about 30 residents of Ak-Suu gathered for a rally protesting against alleged illegal construction at local recreation center and other violations of law related to the facility, as well as being concerned by environmental issues. [size=about 30]

On 13 May 2019, about 20 parents of the Novopavlovka high school students protested at the Maxim Gorky park in Bishkek city demanding resignation of the school principal and shut down of the school's donation fund which protesters insisted wasn't transparent. [size=about 20]

On 13 May 2019, parents gathered in village Novopavlovka in Sokuluk region to protest against gathering money from students by a local school. The parents demanded dismissal of the school director. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
On 10 May, two residents of Zhiyde were reportedly illegally detained and beaten by a local law enforcer of the border service in order to exert money from them.

On 7 May, protesters gathered in Bishkek. They were predominantly health workers and parents of children treated at the National Center of Oncology and Hematology and aimed to support the oncologist recently arrested. According to the photo provided, dozens of protesters participated. [size=dozens]

On 7 May, the representatives of Bereket company, the owner of a part of the Osh bazaar, came to pick up its electrical equipment from the area, because this part of the market was closed. But several dozens (according to a video provided) of sellers gathered for a rally and tried to prevent them from doing so. Later the situation was calmed and the sellers were promised further negotiations. [size=several dozens]

On 6 May, a civilian was reportedly detained and beaten by law enforcers in Alamedin district of Bishkek city. The information was provided by the National Center for the Prevention of Torture. Reportedly, he was beaten and choked in order to provide confession to an alleged crime.

On 6 May, a rally was held in Osh, Kyrgyzstan. Participants demanded those, who had attacked deaf people in the village one week earlier, to be brought to justice. The exact number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 3 May, a picket protest was held by residents of Military Antonovka district of Bishkek. About 30 protesters gathered and almost all were detained by law enforcers. Predominantly they were also soon released, one protester was fined, and all of them were banned for organizing rallies for a week. [size=about 30]

On 2 May 2019, residents of village Internatsionalnoye in Ysyk-Ata district organized a protest against movement of large vehicles of a mining company. The villagers claimed that the vehicles damage their central road. [size=no report]

On 2 May, around 50 protesters gathered in Karakol, protesting against uranium mining in Kyrgyzstan. Activists and organizers believe that the industry puts the environment in danger. [size=around 50]

On 1 May, members of the LGBT-friendly movement '8/365' aimed to gather for a picnic in Bishkek, but the event was disrupted by around 10 men, wearing traditional hats, verbally attacking the participants. Reportedly, law enforcers were close, but refused to interfere. Later, the picnickers decided rather to move to a safer location. [size=around 10]

On 30 April, protesters gathered in Balykchy, protesting against the development of the Tash-Bulak uranium deposit in Issyk-Kul and for public hearings on this matter. Around 500 protesters gathered for the event. The event was a part of wider string of demonstrations against the deposit. [size=around 500]

On 30 April, over 20 people gathered with pickets in the center of Bishkek, protesting against the development of the Tash-Bulak uranium deposit in Issyk-Kul and for public hearings on this matter. The event was co-organized by the Green party of Kyrgyzstan. [size=over 20]

On 30 April 2019, 20-30 supporters of imprisoned former lawmaker Sadyr Japarov protested at the Supreme Court hearing in Bishkek city demanding his release from prison and drop all charges against him. Protesters called the case a political witch hunt ahead of parliamentary elections in 2020. [size=20-30]

On 29 April 2019, hundreds of protesters gathered in the centre of Balykchy, protesting against the development of the Tash-Bulak uranium deposit in Issyk-Kul and for public hearings on this matter. The event was a part of the wider string of demonstrations against the deposit. [size=hundreds]

On 29 April 2019, dozens of parents of the high school students in Novopavlovka village in Sokuluk district protested on the premises against negative public campaign toward the school's leadership and parents initiated donation fund. Protesters insisted the school's fund is transparent and their kids are receiving the best support because of it. [size=dozens]

On 29 April, residents of Alai, Osh region attacked a group of disabled (deaf) people on a false information; thinking that they were pedophiles and wanted to abduct local children. They were beaten and their car was damaged. Later it appeared that the rumor had been spread by children, who had previously harassed the deaf people themselves. [size=no report]

On 28 April 2019, about 4 residents of the Tajik exclave Vorukh threw stones at the Kyrgyz villager's pickup truck damaging the vehicle's windshield near the village of Ak-Sai. Kyrgyz villager was driving through Vorukh because that is the only road Kyrgyz villagers use to get to the pastureland outside the Tajik village. [size=about 4]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security

On 26 April, three members of the State Committee for National Security attacked other visitors of a cafe Bakhai. A private guard of the cafe tried to calm them, but was taken out, attacked and stabbed. Later he was hospitalized and all three attackers (possibly drunk) were detained.

On 26 April, protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek, protesting against development of the Tash-Bulak uranium deposit in Issyk-Kul and for public hearings on this matter. About 300 protesters reported. The event was a part of wider string of demonstrations against the deposit. [size=about 300]

On 25 April, protesters gathered in Koi-Tash village, near the private residency of the former President Atambayev. They said that they participated in the revolution in 2010 and now are calling for further development and improving of living conditions in the country. According to the photos, around a dozen of protesters participated. [size=around a dozen]

On 25 April 2019, 5-10 residents of Amir-Temur neighborhood in Osh city protested against the construction of a gasoline station near their homes demanding the shutdown of the project. Protesters argued that the lands of a daycare and a playground facility are included in the construction plan of the station. [size=5-10]

On 24 April 2019, about 50 protesters gathered outside the White House in Bishkek city, predominantly parents of Novopavlovka village high school students in Sokuluk district, demanding information about financial affairs of the school due to suspicions that funds were misused. Protesters called for the resignation of the high school director and shut down of the school's donation fund. [size=about 50]

On 24 April 2019, 5-10 environmental activists protested at the Tash-Bulak uranium deposit near Kok-Moinok village demanding shut down of the project. Protesters stopped a cargo truck which was coming out of the mine during a protest and ordered a driver to open the trailer and let protesters check on the cargo items. No violent interaction. [size=5-10]
On 24 April 2019, security staff of Osh airport organized a protest and demanded dismissal of their boss. The protesters claimed that the director mistreats the employees. [size=no report]

On 23 April, around 500 protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek near the Highest court, calling for release of political figures currently facing their trial. The rally is attended by members of the Ata Meken party. [size=around 500]

On 22 April, violent demonstrations of local Tajik and Kyrgyz villagers occurred in their respective villages in the border area. Reportedly, a young Kyrgyz boy was taken from a settlement Ak-Sai onto the Tajik territory - Tojikon settlement (Isfara district, Vorukh). Although the boy was immediately returned, at least 50 Kyrgyz locals from Ak-Sai spontaneously gathered expressing their anger - blocked a road and vandalized several Tajik vehicles, as well as Tajiks damaged a Kyrgyz one in their area. Three Tajiks were detained. [size=at least 50]

On 22 April 2019, about 300 people gathered at the Tash-Bulak uranium deposit near Kok-Moinok village in Ton district of Issyk-Kul region, demanding the mining of uranium to be stopped due to its potential evironmental effects. [size=about 300]

On 22 April 2019, about 8 construction workers protested at the construction site near the International University of Science and Business on 7-April street in Bishkek city demanding their back pay from the private contractor whom protesters accused of improper conduct after they finished a job. [size=about 8]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 22 April, residents of Kyrgyz settlements around the border with Vorukh exclave attacked with stones a Tajik taxi and tractors and its drivers, carrying passengers to Vorukh, and damaged them. Following the incident and due to tensions among the Tajik and Kyrgyz inhabitants, the armed forces of Kyrgyzstan intervened. [size=no report]

On 22 April, protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek, protesting against development of the Tash-Bulak uranium deposit in Issyk-Kul and for public hearings on this matter. The event was a part of wider string of demonstrations against the deposit. [size=no report]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 22 April, around 50 protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek - predominantly supporters of the former President Atambayev and members of the Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan. They were calling for resignation of the Minister of Justice. [size=around 50]

On 19 April 2019, about 50 shop owners of the Bereket market at the Osh bazaar in Bishkek city rioted against the market management's move to close down the market and restrict access to the shop owners resulting in rioters storming through the locked rear entrance gate and kicking several security guards out of the market. Rioting shop owners demanded full access to their shops. [size=about 50]

On 19 April 2019, residents of village Kok-Moinok in Ton district organized a protest against planned mining of uranium in the area. They claimed that mining would be dangerous for their health. [size=no report]

On 18 April 2019, 30-40 residents of Kara-Jygach village in Suzak district of Jalal-Abad region protested in the village against sublease of agricultural land to them by the local farmer. The protesters argued he may have violated national laws on cropland use. The Protesters demanded the district authorities resolve disputes and lease land without a middleman. [size=30-40]

On 17 April, traders of the Osh-market in Bishkek gathered for a protest against higher rental prices and fees, and against other measures taken by authorities after the recent arson at the market. According to the video, dozens of individuals participated. [size=dozens]

On 16 April, rights defenders gathered near the Pervomay district court in Bishkek in order to support employees of State Registration Service, who were facing their trial there over alleged involvement in an illegal tender. [size=no report]

On 11 April 2019, about 100 small shop owners of the Bereket market at the Osh bazaar in Bishkek city protested outside their shops against closure of the market which protesters claimed wasn't known to them until the last minute. Protesters insisted it was illegal to shut down the market without at least a month prior advance notice. [size=about 100]
On 9 April, around 100 protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek to support the ex-chairman of the NSC of Kyrgyzstan, demanding his immediate release. [size=around 100]

On 8 April 2019, about 40 residents of Sur and Ormosh villages protested in Sur village in Kadamjai district of Batken region against the local authorities' inaction to prevent infrequent conflicts between the youths of two townships. They also demanded from the district administration to build a separate school for Sur village. The protesters argued conflicts occur due to shared use of one primary school in Ormosh village. [size=about 40]

On 3 April 2019, 20-30 parents protested outside the local high school in Novopavlovka village in Sokuluk district of Chui region against mandatory monthly cash contribution to the school board demanding principal disclose financial records. [size=20-30]

On 28 March 2019, about 30 tenants of a residence hall on Kasymbekova street in Osh city protested outside their homes against court-ordered eviction from their dormitory which protesters argued has been a permanent place of residence for them since the 2000s. Protesters appealed to the country's president to intervene their dispute with a new owner of the building. [size=about 30]

On 28 March, a resident of Bishkek was arrested and beaten by law enforcers, because he accidentally hit their car with a stone. Allegedly, he was later forced to sign a statement that he injured himself. Later he had to be transferred to a hospital.

On 28 March, the President of Russia and the President of Kyrgyzstan signed an agreement in Bishkek on expanding the Russian military base in Kant, Kyrgyzstan, by 60 hectares and equipment supporting usage of drones.

On 27 March, a rally was held in Bishkek in front of the Russian embassy on the eve of the planned visit of Russian President to Kyrgyzstan. On the posters that were carried by the protesters were inscriptions such as 'Putin is the aggressor', 'Occupant', 'Killer' and also 'We don't need a military base'. Kyrgyz police considered these announcements as a call for ethnic hatred and detained two of the protesters. [size=no report]

On 26 March, a protest was held in front of the mayor's office in Balykchy by the residents of the city. The protest was organized against the development of the Tash-Bulak alluvial uranium deposit in the Ton district. The event was a part of wider string of demonstrations against the deposit. [size=no report]

On 25 March, a protest was held in front of the mayor's office in Bishkek by forty mothers of children infected with HIV from 2004 to 2007 in the hospitals of Kara-Suu, Nookat and Ozgonsky districts. [size=40]
On 20 March, around 20 protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek to support the ex-chairman of the NSC of Kyrgyzstan, demanding his immediate release. [size=around 20]

On 20 March, around 15 residents of Kara-Suu district gathered for a rally, calling for resignation for the head of local administration. Reportedly, police officers asked the protesters to leave, but without any further intervention. [size=around 15]

On 18 March, a protest was held near mayor's office in Bishkek by the residents of the city. The protesters expressed disappointment with conditions in minibuses and demanded their improvement. [size=no report]

On 18 March 2019, about 50 women displaced from Ak-Sai village due to border events protested at the temporary shelter facility in the town of Batken during a meeting with the Kyrgyz government officials, demanding the central authorities to resolve the border disputes with Tajikistan without further delay due to recurring conflicts on the border. [size=about 50]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

As reported on 17 March, law enforcers of Kyrgyzstan had blocked the way into the Vorukh enclave resided by Tajiks for several days following the unrests of 13rd March. Neither representatives of the Red Cross, nor any other were allowed to go through; not even sick or injured Tajiks from the exclave were allowed to get out to seek help.
On 17 March, a requiem rally for those killed in the Aksy events took place on Ala-Too Square in Bishkek. [size=no report]

On 15 March 2019, about 50 protesters demonstrated near the village of Ak-Sai in Batken region at the meeting with the Kyrgyz parliament and government officials demanding the central authorities resolve the border dispute with Tajikistan. [size=about 50]

On 14 March, protesters gathered in Bakai-Ata district, Talas oblast, [coded to Bakai-Ata] calling for closing development of the Shyralzhyn mining field. The protests are linked to a disappearance of an employer of the field, who went missing in January. The exact numbers of protesters was not revealed, but according to photos there were dozens of individuals. [size=dozens]

On 13 March, a rally of the public association 'Kyrk Choro' was held near the city hall building in Bishkek. The participants of the rally protested for banning LGBT 'propaganda' and against the march organized by feminist groups on March 8. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

On 13 March, hundreds of Tajiks and Kyrgyz pelted one another with rocks in the village of Ak-Sai, Batken Oblast, because of a disagreement over a road currently under construction in the disputed section of the Tajik-Kyrgyz border. According to 24kg, firearms also have been deployed. Kyrgyzstan's border guards intervened and stopped the conflict. During the collision, one or two of the Tajik people died (according to various resources), and more than 20 were injured.

On 12 March 2019, about 30 retail shop owners protested at the Dordoi clothing market in Bishkek city against proposed high tariffs on imported goods from China and other foreign states demanding the Kyrgyz government keeps tariffs low or else they will go out of business because of it. [size=about 30]

On 11 March, five women were protesting in Naryn against the decision of local government to demolish their trade objects and even announced their preparedness to start a hunger strike. Later they managed to set an appointment with the local governor and decided to disperse. [size=5]
BBC News; Gezitter; AKIpress; Sanjar Kalmatai

On 11 March 2019, 40 women organized a protest against the movement 'Feminist Initiative' in Bishkek. They disagreed with the opinion that 'the rights of girls are not protected in Kyrgyzstan. Likewise, about 8 members of Kyrk Choro movement protested outside the city administration in Bishkek city demanding Mayor's resignation for allowing the women's rights and LGBT march in the city a few days earlier. [size=about 48]
Knews; Gezitter; TAG News Agency; AKIpress; RFE/RL; 24Kg; BBC News

On 8 March, an annual march for women's rights was held in Bishkek. Some protesters carried banners and posters in support of the LGBT community. Following the protest, representatives of the 'Kirk Choro' movement announced that they considered the event as a gay parade and demanded the resignation of the Mayor. [size=no report]

On 7 March 2019, about 15 farmers protested outside the local administration in the town of Taran-Bazar of Suzak district against land auction which protesters argued was conducted without their knowledge. Protesters complained they grow crops on the land that was put up for auction by the local officials. [size=about 15]

On 4 March 2019, about 40 meat shop workers protested outside the city administration's office in Osh city after the local authorities shut down seven meat shops in the city due to unsafe sanitary conditions in the meat processing facilities. [size=about 40]

On 4 March 2019, about 10 neighborhood residents protested at the construction site on Jibek-Jolu street in Bishkek city against the construction of multi-storey apartment building next to their residential homes and demanded to halt the construction activity. Protesters accused the developer company of making fraudulent claims in order to collect approval signatures from the neighborhood folks. [size=about 10]

On 27 February 2019, 15-20 residents of the Turk-Abad village in Suzak district of Jalal-Abad region protested in town against the local councilman whom they voted for accusing him of misleading them before election and falsely promising land plots. [size=15-20]

On 26 February, law enforcers of the Oktyabrsky district, Bishkek, reportedly detained and severely beaten a local resident. He ended up with broken spine and other injuries. Later he was hospitalized.

On 25 February 2019, 30-40 residents of Papan village protested outside the Osh regional court building in Osh city demanding justice in the case involving a land dispute between them and former Papan village administration official, whom protesters accused of corruption which inflicted land property losses. Protesters claimed former official distributed their public land to outsiders and relatives in exchange for cash. [size=30-40]

On 23 February, police physically intimidated a lawyer at a police station in Bishkek who was defending the case of a Christian man who had been attacked in Tamchy in October 2018. Police officers reportedly insulted her and the Christian faith, pushed her against the wall and demanded her to drop the case. She fell ill with heart problems as a result, but police prevented her from taking an ambulance to the hospital. After the lawyer was released she was hospitalized for two days. Authorities later denied that the incident had taken place. [coded according to civilian's version]

On 22 February, around 50 protesters gathered in Bishkek. They were predominantly parents of students of a local Turkish school, protesting against the dismissal of the director of the school. He was accused of pedophilia, but the parents claim that all accusations are false and expressed their support to the director. [size=around 50]
Former Military Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-); Military Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-); Government of Kyrgyzstan (2017-)

On 15 February, a requiem rally was organized in Bishkek. The rally was dedicated to the 29th anniversary of the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan. Veterans of hostilities in Afghanistan, their relatives, representatives of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Kyrgyz Republic, the mayor of the capital and other people took part in the rally. They laid wreaths at the monument of the fallen soldiers and honored their memory with a minute of silence. [size=no report]

As reported on 8 March, in February 2019 around 10 people attacked a Muslim man in Tamchy for being a friend with a Christian man who had been beaten up over his faith in October 2018. Threats against Christians flared up after this incident.

On 14 February 2019, 15-20 residents of the village of Burgondu in Kadamjai district of Batken region protested against several members of the Jehovas Witness Christian religious group who were in town to promote their group's beliefs among villagers. [size=15-20]

On 6 February, around 100 protesters gathered in Bishkek. They were protesting against the chairman of the Federation of Trade unions, demanding his dismissal, reportedly due to his insufficient working performance. Later they declared that they are ready to hold another rally again. [size=around 100]

On 1 February 2019, about 10 clients of Amanbank protested outside its branch office in the town of Kurshab in Uzgen district demanding the bank make the refund of their deposits, which protesters complained they couldn't withdraw out of the bank for months as Amanbank denied having their funds. [size=about 10]

On 30 January, a handful of shareholders of a construction company who at that moment were under arrest, held a protest near the White House in Bishkek demanding finishing of the housing construction and removing the arrest from the construction company facilities. [size=a handful]

On 28 January, a handful of staff of the Department of Eye Microsurgery of the National Hospital no.1 held a protest near the White House in Bishkek, demanding the dismissal of the head of the Department. The reason for the protest was the misuse of professional position by the head of the Department in personal interests. [size=a handful]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force

In the night of 25-26 January, at Dunlarova military checkpoint in Tokmok, one of the border guards was the nephew of a government deputy and had unlawfully shot unarmed civilians (a car was riddled with bullets and one person injured), thinking they were smugglers. The authorities denied the event for three days.

On 24 January 2019, about 10 residents of Kurmanjan Datka neighborhood in Osh city protested near their homes against the takeover of their backyard and playground by private buyers demanding the city authorities cancel purchase transaction involving their land and protect their ownership rights. [size=about 10]

On 23 January 2019, dozens of employees of the state-owned circus protested outside the Ministry of Culture in Bishkek city against the appointment of the new director demanding Kyrgyz officials support their own candidate for the directorship of the circus. [size=dozens]

On 23 January 2019, a group of Tajik residents from Lackan village protested on the borderline near Kara-Bak village in Batken, against the Kyrgyz villagers-built shade structure on the disputed land near the village, demanding its demolition. It sparked a counter-protest by a group of Kyrgyz villagers who have argued it was agreed upon by both sides previously. [size=no report]
Kaktus Media; Kloop; Gezitter; Kyrgyztoday; AKIpress

On 21 January, a handful of State Circus actors held a protest near the White House in Bishkek. The main requirement of the protesters was the approval of the candidate for the position of the director of the State Circus nominated by the team that had been remained unfilled for over a month. [size=a handful]

On 21 January 2019, about 20 residents of Safarovka village in Jalal-Abad region protested near the local school against closure and transfer of the town's public school to the private business. The protesters also demanded the Suzak district's head of administration resign because of his decision regarding transfer. [size=about 20]

On 21 January 2019, 20-30 traders protested at the local bazaar near the railroad station in Jalal-Abad city against the takeover of their market by the private entrepreneur who launched construction works at the bazaar without notifying protesters in advance. Protesters complained they were told of upcoming rent raises which they opposed and demanded the city administration intervene in the dispute. [size=20-30]

On 18 January, in Bishkek, a large group of Kyrgyz citizens took part in a rally in honor of the 76th anniversary of the breakthrough of the blockade of Leningrad. The participants of the rally laid flowers and honored the memory of those who died during the blockade by a minute of silence.[size=large group]

On 18 January, a handful of journalists of the newspaper 'Super-Info' and Next TV channel held a protest in front of the building of Bishkek State Police Department. They declared inadmissibility of the cruelty of the police against journalists when covering mass events referring to the anti-Chinese protest happened on 17 January when a journalist of Next TV was detained by the police. [size=a handful]

On 17 January, about 70 residents of Tash-Aryk village in Kyrgyzstan held a protest near the museum complex 'Manas Ordo', demanding the dismissal of the director of the museum. The reason for the protest was repeated accusations of the female employees of the museum in the harassment by the director. [size=about 70]
Caravan; 24Kg; Interfax; Gezitter; The Times of Central Asia; Fergana News; RFE/RL; TAG News Agency; Kabar; BBC News; Kaktus Media; Kyrgyztoday; AKIpress; Kloop; Zakon; Ozodagon; Intellinews

On 17 January, about 500 people held a protest on Ala-Too Square in Bishkek against China's 're-education camps'. The participants of the protest urged Kyrgyz authorities to deport illegal Chinese migrants. They also demanded the government stop giving citizenship to foreigners who marry Kyrgyz nationals. The protest was dispersed by the police with 17 people detained and 21 people charged with fines. [size=about 500]

On 16 January 2019, about 20 residents of the Dacha-Suu village in Sokuluk district protested at the memorial monument to the victims of air crash in 2017 demanding the Kyrgyz government deliver on its promises to fix the village infrastructure and roads. [size=about 20]

On 15 January 2019, about 30 grocery store owners protested on Kulatova street in Osh city against the city administration's plan to remove their businesses off the street and proceed forward with the renovation project in the neighborhood which protesters categorically opposed. Protesters accused the city authorities of organizing intimidation campaign against them by dispatching city police officers to force them out of the neighborhood. [size=about 30]
On 15 January, about 30 market traders held a protest at Orto-Sai market in Bishkek, demanding to stop increasing the rent of the retail outlets. [size=about 30]
On 11 January, in Ananyevo, Issyk Kul, Kyrgyzstan, a Christian cemetery was desecrated by unknown vandals, who damaged 89 gravestones. Christian cemeteries have been targeted more often in the past.

As reported on 11 January, in Bishkek, a group of men threatened a transgender man with a gun and forced him to strip and demanded to insert a bottle of champagne into his rectum. They posted a video of the event on social media. Authorities denied that it had taken place in Bishkek.

On 11 January 2019, 15-20 taxi drivers protested outside Tolubai cafe in Balykchy city against the new road safety and public conduct laws which carry steep fines for breaking traffic rules and public misconduct. [size=15-20]

On 8 January 2019, about 30 residents of Safarovka village in Suzak district protested at the local high school and daycare complex against the authorities' plan to reorganize a complex by separating school and daycare into different entities which have sparked opposition from the local population that believes such move would negatively impact their children. [size=about 30]
Kyrgyztoday; TAG News Agency; Gezitter; The Times of Central Asia; RFE/RL; Intellinews

On 7 January 2019, about 300 people held a protest on Ala-Too Square in Bishkek demanding to deport illegal Chinese migrants from the country. The participants of the protest also urged not to allow the marriage of Kyrgyz women with Chinese citizens and expressed their concerns about the relevant laws that had recently entered into force. [size=about 300]

On 4 January 2019, 20-30 residents of Kok-Moinok village protested against the nearby uranium mining project Tash-Bulak on the deposit premises in Issyk-Kul region demanding complete shut down of the mining activity due to environmental concerns. [size=20-30]

On 29 December 2018, 20-30 grocery store owners protested near their shops on Kulatova street in Osh city against the city administration's plan to remove their businesses off the street and turn it into an alley. Protesters urged the city Mayor to proceed forward with a plan in accordance with their concerns. [size=20-30]
On 28 December, several citizens gathered in Bishkek to demand tougher punishment for sexual child abuse. [size=several]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security
On 28 December, a detainee complained of being tortured by law enforcement officers in Osh while being detained for preparing 'terrorist' attacks.
Around 28 December, residents of Min-Bulak held a general gathering to speak out against gold mining on the summer pasture of Solton-Sary. [size=no report]

On 27 December 2018, about 300 residents of Min-Bulak village in Naryn region protested in the their town against the Chinese mining company managed gold project Solton Sary demanding halt to mining activity in the area due to environmental concerns. [size=about 300]

On 25 December 2018, about 30 residents of the village of Boz-Adyr protested at the local administration demanding answers regarding rumors of possible transfer of their nearby land and water source to the neighboring Uzbekistan. [size=about 30]

On 24 December, residents of Military Antonovka, Bishkek district gathered in the center, calling deputies to take a legal decision on the land transferring. According to photos provided, dozens of protesters gathered. [size=dozens]

On 24 December 2018, 50-100 residents of Kara-Suu district in Osh region protested outside their local administration in the village of Nariman demanding the immediate resignation of the head of the township due to a court verdict which concluded that the town official's education certificate was forged. Protesters accused town official of corruption after alleged non-transparent deals with public land plots which were designated for the district residents. [size=50-100]
On 22 December, members of the Ata Meken party participated in a march celebrating the 60th birthday of the jailed Ata-Meken leader in Bazar-Korgon. [size=no report]

On 20 December, about 200 persons gathered near the Chinese embassy in Bishkek to demand that the authorities of Kyrgyzstan expel within 30 days foreigners illegally residing in Kyrgyzstan. The organization Kyrgyz Chorolor was involved in the protest. This occurred in the context of protests against the oppression of ethnic minorities in Xinjiang, China. [size=about 200]
On 18 December, four detainees were beaten and reported torture by law enforcement officers while being transferred from the court to the detention center in Bishkek.

Around 18 December 2018, about 50 workers building the Balykchy-Korumdu road gathered in Cholpon-Ata to protest against the non-payment of their salaries since the summer of the same year. [size=about 50]

On 17 December 2018, a group of residents of Bishkek organized a protest after the government started demolishing their houses. The government representatives claimed that the houses had been constructed illegally. The protesters demanded a meeting with the authorities. [size=no report]

On 17 December, about 10 Chinese Kyrgyz gathered in front of the building of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Kyrgyzstan in Bishkek as part of the wave of protests against the detention of minorities in Xinjiang China. [size=about 10]

As reported on 8 March 2019, in December 2018 a Protestant Christian man was beaten by several men in a local market in Tamchy who shouted 'we know you are a Christian wand we will punish you'. He left the village afterwards for fears for his safety. Two months earlier another Christian man had been severely beaten up.
On 14 December, an action against the smog started in Bishkek. A rally was organized for the occasion. [size=no report]

On 14 December 2018, about 15 victims of shopping centre fire at the Osh Bazaar in Bishkek city protested near the market demanding the city authorities allow them to operate their makeshift shops close to bazaar after suffering financial losses due to fire accident. [size=about 15]

On 10 December, a former employee of the Junda plant where violation of workers' right were decried, was beaten by unidentified individuals in Kara-Balta ahead of the visit of parliament's deputies in the city. He was previously threatened and beaten in November.

On 10 December 2018, 5-10 homeowners protested near the hippodrome in Bishkek city against the city administration's plan to expropriate their land and homes due to conflicting property ownership claims. Protesters insisted they have legitimate documents to prove their homeownership rights. [size=5-10]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 7 December 2018, several supporters of the former Kyrgyz president protested at the Social Democratic Party's press-conference in Bishkek city against the party's new leadership demanding former president retains his chairmanship of the party. Security was called in to escort the protesters out of the building. [size=several]

On 7 December 2018, about 10 clients of Amanbank protested outside its local branch in the town of Kurshab in Uzgen district of Osh region demanding their deposits back from the bank. Protesters complained they couldn't withdraw their life savings appealing to the country's president for assistance. [size=about 10]

On 6 December 2018, about 100 protesters demonstrated in the town of Batken against dismissal of their representative in the central government's regional office demanding his job back and reinstatement in the position of deputy. [size=about 100]

On 6 December 2018, about 20 residents of Yntymak village in Uzgen district of Osh region protested near their homes against the alleged mob-tied local family demanding them to move out of village. Protesters complained they were physically assaulted and threatened with a knife by particular family members on numerous occasions. [size=about 20]

On 5 December 2018, about 20 people gathered in front of the office of the United Nations in Bishkek to raise attention to the situation of minorities including Uyghurs, detained in re-education camps in Xinjiang China. [size=about 20]

On 5 December, residents of Bishkek gathered in the center of the capital. They claim that they can be left without houses due to the illegal actions of the prosecutor's office. According to photos provided, dozens of protesters gathered. [size=dozens]

On 4 December 2018, about 100 residents of Terek-Sai village protested against the detention of their 15 fellow villagers who were probed by police for assaulting several policemen on 5 November 2018 at the nearby gold mining project over trespassing incident. [size=about 100]

On 4 December 2018, about 10 clients of the Aman bank demonstrated outside the bank's office in the town of Kurshab of Uzgen district demanding their deposits back after bank failed to return it. Protesters called for the Kyrgyz authorities to revoke the bank's license until they will receive their money back. [size=about 10]

On 4 December 2018, 30-40 road construction workers protested at the a company's field office in Kyzyl-Kia town of Batken region, demanding their back pay for more than 6 months of work. Protesters complained the company has been dodging them for weeks which forced protesters to take up the issue with the government. [size=30-40]

On 3 December, about 200 residents of the village of Terek-Say gathered in Terek-Say near Buzuk to demanded the release of the 17 persons who were arrested after fighting with law enforcement. They also demand employment opportunities in the area and protest against the proximity of a plant using cyanide nearby. [size=about 200]

In early December, police officers in Penal Colony 31 in Chui region [coded to Bishkek] tortured a prisoner to confess to a murder, ignoring a court verdict that pleaded him not guilty and ordered him to be released from custody.

On 29 November 2018, about 15 clients of Amanbank protested outside the branch of the bank in the town of Kurshab of Uzgen district in Osh region demanding their deposits back from the bank which protesters accused of running a scam. Protesters complained they couldn't withdraw funds for nearly 6 months and called for the Kyrgyz authorities to cancel Amanbank's license. [size=about 15]

On 26 November 2018, about 100 protesters demonstrated outside the Batken regional administration office in the town of Batken demanding the fair investigation of the murder of a regional prosecutor. [size=about 100]

On 23 November, about 9000 people gathered in Osh to march against terrorism and extremism. There are claims that students and school children were forced to participate in the march. [size=about 9000]
Around 23 November, veterans of the Batken gathered in Bishkek to protest against the non-payment of their annual social benefits to the families killed during the Batken event. [size=no report]

On 22 November, veterans of the Batken events of 2000 and their family members staged a rally in Bishkek, complaining about non-payment of annual benefits. The number of protesters was not revealed. [size=no report]
Around 21 November, residents of the Muras-Ordo residential complex gathered in Bishkek to demand the opening of a new public transport route. [size=no report]

On 19 November, a bisexual man in the Issyk-Kul region [coded as Karakol] was kidnapped by police officers, who beat him, poured vodka in his mouth and carved the word 'gay' in large letters on his stomach with a knife. They did so in response to a report he filed at the police station about another homophobic attack he had suffered a few days before. His mother transferred him to a private hospital because state hospital refused to take care of him. He left the country soon after.

Around 19 November, the suspect arrested in the case of the murder of a prosecutor was subject to torture in Batken. The prosecutor's general office denied this claim stating instead that the accusation was made in order to avoid responsibility for the murder. [coded to the version of the civilian]
On 19 November, about 30 doctors gathered in Bishkek to protest against the optimization of family medicine centers proposed by the government. [size=about 30]

On the night of 18 November, the prosecutor of the Batken region was killed from a blow in the head with a blunt object. The body was found in the outskirt of Batken near the Tort-Kul reservoir, and a suspect was identified.
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 16 November 2018, about 150 supporters of former presidential adviser Ikramjan Ilmiyanov (from SPDK) protested in the town of Katran of Leilek district against arrest and detention of former aide demanding his release to house arrest. Protesters appealed to the Kyrgyz president for intervention in the case and fair investigation. [size=about 150]

On 13 November 2018, 40-50 health workers protested outside the Ministry of Health in Bishkek city against proposed optimisation in the country's healthcare which protesters argued would lead to work overload for underpaid medics, and understaffed clinics and hospitals. Protesters called for the top-ranking health officials not to mislead the public regarding average monthly pay for medics which is not 30,000 Som as the health authorities announced previously. [size=40-50]
TAG News Agency; RFE/RL; Kabar; Fergana News
On 9 November, an unidentified individual stabbed a journalist known for discussing social issues in her work, in Jalal-Abad.

On 9 November 2018, more than 10 local activists protested in Jalal-Abad against excessive police action to discourage them from participating in the meeting of opposition groups which has happened on 8 November in Osh city. They were unable to attend a gathering due to police intervention. The protesters also demanded the Kyrgyz government to reduce the number of lawmakers in the country's parliament, create jobs and introduce moratorium to stop price hikes on utilities. [size=more than 10]

Around 7 November, three persons were injured as a result of a demonstration that took place in the village of Terek-Say near Buzuk. The rally rose after one local was refused access to a path by members of a special training detachment from Jalal-Abad and the beating of a local residents. Two soldiers and one local resident were wounded. This occurred in the context of demonstration against the activities of mining companies in the area. [size=no report]
Zakon; Ozodagon; TAG News Agency; Fergana News; Kaktus Media; Knews

On 6 November, deputy of the Zhanyzher assembly was attacked and shot several times and died on November 17 in a hospital. According to the investigators, the attack was related to his political activities.

On 5 November 2018, about 15 rioters from the village of Terek-Sai in Chatkal district of Jalal-Abad region physically attacked several policemen at the nearby Eti Bakyr Terek Sai gold mining project which was triggered by an earlier conflict between a local villager and policemen over trespassing incident involving villager's cattle. [size=about 15]

On 5 November 2018, about 20 residents of Zhoon-Kungoi village in Suzak district of Jalal-Abad region protested in the village against lack of attention from the local authorities to their issues regarding access to drinking water. Protesters complained local officials have promised them to fix the problem but it was never delivered. [size=about 20]

In the beginning of November 2018, a worker of the Junda plant was beaten by unidentified individuals in Kara-Balta. The plant which had been described for not paying the salaries of its workers. He was previously warned not to interfere in the case.

On 31 October, approximately 50 people claiming to be supporters of a former Presidential advisor held a protest in front of Bishkek City Court demonstrating against his arrest. [size=approximately 50]
On 31 October, 50 builders of the Balykchy-Tamchy-Korumdu motorway gathered in Balykchy to protest against the non-payment of their wages for three months. [size=50]

On 31 October 2018, about 20 residents of Tashtak village in Suzak district protested at the local water pump demanding the Kyrgyz-Kuwaiti charity fund As-Salam fix the issue with water supply for more than 20 households, after the fund installed the equipment previously but then cut water supply of a group of residents. [size=about 20]
On 31 October, workers building the Balykchy-Korumdu road gathered in Cholpon-Ata to strike against the non-payment of their salaries since the summer of the same year. [size=no report]

Around 25 October 2018 (as reported), a group of local residents protested against the construction of new houses on the main road in the village of Jany-Turmush in Kara-Suu district. [size=no report]
SDPK: Social Democratic Party of Kyrgyzstan

On 24 October 2018, 50-60 supporters of former presidential adviser Ikramjan Ilmiyanov who was a member of the ruling SDPK political faction protested in the village of Katran in Leilek district of Batken region against his detention demanding fair investigation of his case and change his pretrial detention to house arrest. [size=50-60]

On 24 October 2018, there was a brawl between the residents of Batken and representatives of a gold mining company who came to the city to take samples. The locals did not allow experts to work. Police interfered to calm down the citizens. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2018, 50-60 residents of Maidan village protested against the gold project of a Chinese mining company Shambesai in Kadamjai district. Police was called in to disperse the protesters. [size=50-60]
24Kg; Knews; Fergana News; Kloop; Vecherniy Bishkek

On 19 October, police detained a man in Ak-Suu district for allegedly having stolen three sheep, after which he was found dead in a field later that day. According to his father, police officers put a bag over his head during interrogation and beat him to death with water bottles. The police reported that he had committed suicide. An investigation into torture was nonetheless undertaken, and 17 police officials were officially reprimanded.

On 16 October 2018, about 3 female protesters demonstrated in Jalal-Abad city demanding the country's president and government to reduce the number of lawmakers in the parliament from 120 to 35. Protesters called for electoral system reform to boost the proportional representation in the Kyrgyz parliament. [size=about 3]

On 16 October, in Tamchy, Issyk Kul, Kyrgyzstan, a Christian man was severely beaten by three men who broke into his home and demanded him to renounce his faith and convert to Islam. He suffered from a broken jaw and severe bruising. The authorities denied that the attack was religiously motivated and the attackers were not persecuted.

On 11 October 2018, about 10 relatives of a deceased victim in a homicide case protested outside the district court in the town of Nookat, Osh, demanding justice and accusing the case judge of corruption as he released the murder suspects from detention. [size=about 10]

On 10 October 2018, about 30 produce market traders protested at the local bazaar near the town of Aravan in Osh region against the takeover of the bazaar by the local authorities. Protesters argued the local administration has never invested funds to improve infrastructure around the market. [size=about 30]

On 9 October 2018, a brief scuffle broke out outside the district court in Kara-Suu township of Osh region between dozens of people who came out to support Papan township Mayor and a group of opponents who accused a Mayor of corruption and abuse of power over an alleged bribery scheme involving land distribution deal. Police were called in to maintain public order at the scene of the altercation. [size=dozens]

On 8 October 2018, several protesters demonstrated outside the White House in Bishkek city demanding the Kyrgyz president intervene in their court case to speed up the hearing process which protesters argued was too slow. [size=several]

On 4 October 2018, 10-15 residents of Kelechek neighborhood near the village of Toguz-Bulak in Leilek district protested against lack of social infrastructure such as school and daycare in the village and demanded proper water supply to their households. Protesters accused the local town administration of corruption due to the illegal practice of selling upscale land plots to wealthy buyers. [size=10-15]

On 3 October, a protest was held by the dismissed teachers of the Republican Olympic Reserve School in Bishkek demanding that they be reinstated at work and that the Director of the school be held accountable for their illegal dismissal. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security

On October 02nd, 2018, during the implementation of a joint operation between the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Kyrgyz Republic and the State National Security Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic, an unspecified number of active members of the banned religious and militant organization Hizb ut-Tahrir were detained in the city of Karakol of Kyrgyz Republic. It was established that the detainees were actively engaged in recruiting new members into their ranks and called for the creation of a theocratic state 'Caliphate'.

On 2 October 2018, about 3 women organized a protest in the business district of Jalal-Abad city against the number of MPs of the country's parliament and demanded from the Kyrgyz government to scale down the parliament's annual budget and reduce the number of lawmakers from 120 to 60 or less. [size=about 3]

On 1 October 2018, more than 10 medics of the Family Medical Center 3 protested outside the clinic in Jalal-Abad city against salary withdrawal for the month of September which protesters argued wasn't consulted with them in advance. Protesters announced they will strike if their concerns aren't addressed. [size=more than 10]

On 28 September 2018, a group of experts came to village Maidan in Kadamjai. Reportedly, they were related to a gold mining company. Their presence angered the locals who oppose gold mining activities in the village. The expers were forced into a container and locked up by the residents. Police arrived at the scene to clear up the conflict. [size=no report]

On 25 September 2018, 20-30 residents of the village of Maidan protested against the Chinese company operated project Shambesai in Kadamjai district after observing a group of Chinese nationals working at the mine. Protesters surrounded the Chinese workers and took them to the mine where they were questioned by the protesters. No violent interaction. [size=20-30]

On 25 September 2018, about 10 residents of Papan township protested outside the city court in Osh city demanding justice for the district officials whom protesters accused of bribery and abuse of power. Protesters complained they victimised by improper land distribution deal. [size=about 10]
Knews; TAG News Agency; RFE/RL; Ozodagon; 24Kg; ITAR-TASS; AKIpress; Kyrgyztoday
On 18 September, about 1000 people took part in a march in support of the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in Bishkek. [size=about 1000]

On 18 September 2018, dozens of residents of Kok-Serek village, which is near the town of Tengi in Ala-Buka district, demonstrated in the town hall of Tengi town during the meeting of the Kazakhmys company, demanding an investigation into the death of a local villager who worked at the nearby gold mine Bozumchak managed by the company. The scuffle broke out between one demonstrator and the company staffer. [size=dozens]

On 14 September 2018, about 50 residents of the Kyrgyz village of Bakai organized a protest on the borderline near Ak-Sai village against the installation of water pipe on the disputed borderland by the residents of the Tajik neighborhood of Vorukh exclave, Isfara district. About 60 Tajik villagers gathered on the other side of the border and protested against the Kyrgyz counterparts' claim over a contested piece of land. [size=about 110]

On 11 September 2018, Pervomaysky district police officer discharged his service weapon at the Imperiya Pizza restaurant on Akhunbayev street in Bishkek city wounding a civilian after brawl between a group of policemen and customers on the premises.

On 6 September 2018, more than 50 kidney dialysis patients protested outside the Ministry of Health in Bishkek city demanding the health authorities provide them with safe medication for treatment rather than cheap and unsafe drugs which people with kidney conditions insisted have side effects. [size=more than 50]
On 27 August, residents of the Muras-Ordo residential complex gathered in Bishkek to demand the opening of a new public transport route. [size=no report]

On 16 August, residents of buildings located in the village of Tash-Dobo in Kyrgyzstan held a protest at the Kyrgyz Research Institute of Balneology and Rehabilitation. They demanded from the Director of the Institute to provide them with water or return the money that was spent by residents of buildings on Sokolnichnaya Street to lay a water line. [size=no report]

On 10 August 2018, an improvised explosive device was detonated on the intersection of Isanova and Ryskulova streets in Bishkek city targeting a Russian businessman at his office. No casualties were reported aside from minor injuries suffered by the Russian national. Kyrgyz media reported this was the second assassination attempt on the same Russian citizen's life after the first one in 2016.
BBC News; TAG News Agency; 24Kg; AKIpress; Knews; Gezitter

On 8 August, about 50 people held a protest at the building of the capital city hall of Kyrgyzstan.
