Activists came to express their protest against one of the candidates for the post of mayor of the capital, who was put forward by a coalition of the majority of the Bishkek City Kenesh. In addition, they demanded the dissolution of the Bishkek City Kenesh. [size=about 50]

On 6 August, police clashed with a group of 4-5 armed men in Balykchy who threw stones and shot at police car as they were being detained. They fled after police fired warning shots, but were soon after arrested. No injuries were reported.

On 6 August 2018, activists organized a protest in Bishkek against the registration of a single candidate for the mayorship of Bishkek. The protesters claimed that the candidate is not suitable for the position. [size=no report]

On 4 August, activists of the Green Party of Kyrgyzstan organized a protest against tree cutting in Bishkek. During the protest the activists were detained by the police. One of the members of the Green Party of Kyrgyzstan was accused of hooliganism and arrested for five days. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
The Right Choice; Gezitter; BBC News; Kyrgyztoday; Kyrgyz National News Agency; Eurasianet; Fergana News

Around 25 July, The State Border Service (SBS) of Kyrgyzstan set up additional roadblocks in the Kyrgyz village of Sary-Tash in connection with the accumulation of radical Islamic militant groups on the borders of the Central Asian republics.
On 17 July, detainees were beaten and reported torture committed by guards of the detention center in Bishkek.

On 16 July, a group of natives of Chui region rallied outside the Parliament building in Bishkek. During the protest, residents of the new buildings of the Chui oblast demanded a transformation of their sections. [size=no report]

On 29 June 2018, 20-30 residents of Ak-Suu village near Kerben town in Aksy district of Jalal-Abad region protested against the nearby gold mining project accusing the mining company of engaging in corruption with the local district officials. Protesters demanded transparency for the mining projects and social benefits for the local villages. [size=20-30]

On 27 June, about a hundred residents of Bakai-Atinsky District hold a rally at the local administration building against gold mining in the Urmaral gorge. They expressed fear that after the start of work, the environment of the district would be harmed, as the chemicals would fall into the water, which was used by the inhabitants of the entire valley. [size=about a hundred]

On 21 June 2018, about 30 construction workers protested at the Maxim Gorky park in Bishkek city against the KG Group company demanding their back pay for months of work which protesters insisted the company owes them. [size=about 30]

On 21 June 2018, a group of residents on Gorky street in Jalal-Abad city protested against the city firefighting service's poor performance when one of the neighborhood homes caught fire threatening neighboring houses. Protesters complained that the fire trucks arrived on the scene without water to extinguish a source of the fire. [size=no report]

On 20 June, in Bishkek a rally was held in front of the Jogorku Kenesh building in support of the arrested Kazakh blogger. At the site of the rally there were relatives of the activist and media representatives. The crowd was watched by security forces. At the protest, his mother asked the President of Kyrgyzstan to intervene in her son's extradition process. [size=no report]

On 18 June, a protest against extradition of Kazakh activist and blogger was held near the building of Kazakhstan's embassy in Bishkek. Blogger's mother, wife and several activists from Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan took part in the rally. [size=no report]

On 18 June 2018, more than 20 residents of the Archa-Beshik neighborhood in Bishkek city protested against bad roads in the area demanding the city authorities fix the local infrastructure and stop ignoring their issues. [size=more than 20]

On 13 June 2018, around 300 protesters gathered in Ala-Buka region against the operations of a gold-mining company. They demanded compensations and asked the authorities to investigate the ecological impact of the mining operations. The authorities met with the protesters. [size=around 300]

On 13 June 2018, several residents and farmers of the Kaytpas village in Kadamjai district of Batken region protested against natural gas pipe removal works on their crop fields demanding a halt to all construction work due to damages inflicted upon their agricultural land. [size=several]

On 9 June, in Bishkek, around 250 people protested against bride kidnapping in the country. The protest was organized and conducted by students. Earlier a man kidnapped a woman with an intention to marry her and stabbed her to death in a police station in northern Chuy Region. [size=around 250]
TAG News Agency; Kaktus Media; Liter

On 6 June, in Bishkek, around 2000 protested against bride kidnapping in the country that has been organized and conducted by students. Earlier a man kidnapped a woman with an intention to marry her and stabbed her to death in a police station in northern Chuy Region [size=around 2000].
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Kyrgyz Frontier Force
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service
RFE/RL; Kloop; Tajikistan Times; NM; Kaktus Media; BBC News; AKIpress; Kyrgyztoday; Asiaplus; TAG News Agency
On 4 June 2018, near Maksat, a gunfight occurred on the state border between Kyrgyz and Tajik border guards. Several Tajik servicemen were captured and restricted by Kyrgyz Border Guards.
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) Prison Guards

Around 4 June 2018 (as reported), prisoners of the penitentiary facility number 27 in Moldovanovka village of Chui region claimed that there was an ongoing torture and mistreatment against them by correction officers. About 70 prisoners cut off their veins and went on hunger strike as a sign of protest. The State Penitentiary Service denied accusations.
On 4 June 2018, in Bishkek, about 30 people protested demanding release of the leaders of El Unu opposition movement. [size=about 30]

On 4 June 2018, about 10 residents of Kurmanjan Datka neighbourhood in Osh city protested against lack of access to the nearby Ak-Buura river which protesters blamed on the local businessman, demanding the city authorities ban any construction activity on the banks of the river. [size=about 10]

On 30 May 2018, about 100 traders of the market in Osh gathered outside the city administration to protest against the decision of the mayor to move their damaged containers to another place. [size=about 100]

On 29 May, about 50 protesters gathered near the Supreme court building in Bishkek, demanding fair trial and justice for the former member of parliament, convicted in 2013 of alleged participation in public unrests. He and his supporters claim that his sentence was politically motivated. [size=about 50]
On 24 May, protesters related to labor unions gathered in Bishkek. They were calling for resignation of the chief of national labor union in Kyrgyzstan. [size=no report]
On 21 May, around 50 protesters gathered in central Bishkek. They were demanding a legal land reform in their respective regions Sokuluk and Alamudun. No detentions were reported. [size=around 50]

On 17 May 2018, 20-30 residents of Turk-Abad village in Suzak district protested against illegal sale of their farmland by the local officials to the non-local buyers demanding criminal investigation and their land plots back. [size=20-30]
On 15 May, a mass brawl erupted between villagers of Kyzyl-Unkur over the cutting down of trees. Three people were injured. [size=no report]
On 15 May, protesters related to labor unions gathered in Bishkek. They were calling for resignation of the chief of national labor union in Kyrgyzstan. [size=no report]

On 15 May, around 50 employers of the company GES Naryn (Нарын ГЭС), Kara-Kul area, gathered for a rally. They claimed that they have not been paid and called authorities to solve the problem; otherwise they may go for another rally to Bishkek. [size=around 50]

On 14 May 2018, about 5 protesters demonstrated outside the General Prosecutor's Office in Bishkek city demanding chief prosecutors investigate an illegal eviction of the family from their home. Protesters complained the district court and local law enforcement are ignoring their case. [size=about 5]

On 14 May, protesters organized by the Green party gathered in the center of Bishkek. They were protesting against cutting trees within the Bishkek city. Around 50 protesters participated. [size=around 50]

On 12 May 2018, more than 50 residents of Ala-Buka town protested against the Chinese mining company operated Istamberdy gold project in the area expressing their concerns for environmental contamination. [size=more than 50]
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 12 May, in Sada, Leilek, Kyrgyzstan [coded to Leilek], Tajik border guards drove about 40-50 meters into Kyrgyz territory and questioned Kyrgyz residents, after which a small altercation occurred between residents and the Tajik border guard. Tajik authorities denied any blame and stated that the territory is disputed. [size=no report]

On 10 May, protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek in order to support the former administrative deputy. They claimed that his trial was not fair and just, but rather chaotic. Around 500 protesters gathered. [size=around 500]

On 10 May, traders of the local bazaar in Osh city gathered for a picket protest in Bishkek near the building of the Parliament. They were calling for financial aid and compensation from the government for their businesses damaged by fire on the market (April 13th). Around 100 protesters reportedly participated. [size=around 100]

On 8 May 2018, about 10 female protesters demonstrated outside the White House in Bishkek city against detention and prosecution of their family members that are suspected of attacking and destroying the Chinese company's gold plant in Toguz Toro district months earlier. [size=about 10]
On 7 May, five policemen beat up a man who was hanging up posters for the 'Immortal Regiment' march, dedicated to Soviet veterans, in Bishkek. He received severe trauma to his head.

On 7 May, protesters gathered in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. They were protesting against administrative moratorium on land transformation in their Alamedin district. According to the attached photo, several dozens of protesters participated. [size=dozens]
On 3 May, a mob attacked a local man in Lipenka, Jeti Oguz, Issyk-Kul, because they suspected him of having molested a young girl. He was hospitalized after. He reportedly had mental problems.

On 26 April 2018, 15-20 residents of Japalak village near Osh city protested against nearby landfill demanding the city authorities relocate it elsewhere due to public health and environmental concerns in the area. [size=15-20]

On 24 April, a rally was organized in the center of Bishkek. Protesters, predominantly interest holders of the Iska-Stroy company, demanded legal assistance, since the head of the company management was imprisoned and accused of fraud. [size=no report]
On 23 April, protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek, demanding release of the detainees, arrested over recent riots in Toguz-Toro area. Dozens protesters reported. [size=dozens]

On 23 April, traders of the Osh market, who suffered during the fire, again went to the rally in the center of Bishkek, demanding larger and faster financial support from the government. The exact number of participants was not reported. [size=no report]
On 19 April, protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek, demanding release of 15 detainees, arrested over recent riots in Toguz-Toro area. Around 30 individuals participated. [size=around 30]

On 19 April, local residents of Ak-Suu district Issyk-Kul region gathered to protest against current status quo of land private ownership and to demand more than hundred ha of land to be given to the village collective. The exact number of participant was not revealed. [size=no report]
On 17 April, protesters again gathered in the center of Bishkek, demanding release of 15 detainees, arrested over recent riots in Toguz-Toro area. Around 50 individuals participated. [size=around 50]

On 17 April 2018, about 20 employees of the Sulaiman-Too museum in Osh city protested on the premises against the unjustified firing of their 2 fellow colleagues by the director and demanded to provide alegal grounds for lay off. The museum director was forced to reinstate 2 employees back on after protest. [size=about 20]

On 16 April, about 50 protesters gathered in Bishkek. The crowd consisted mostly of retailers from the bazaar in Osh, who were affected by recent fire in the market. They demanded legal and material assistance and better protection. [size=about 50]

On 16 April 2018, about 30 villagers of Zhapalak town in Osh city suburb protested against nearby waste dump demanding the city authorities to address the negative environmental impact of the dumpsite on the local population. Protesters complained city officials keep promising to resolve the issue, but there was no solution to the problem yet. [size=about 30]

On 16 April 2018, about 20 private garage owners protested against the demolition of their properties in the Vostok-5 micro-district of Bishkek city demanding the local authorities remove construction equipment and stop all activity near the garage park. [size=about 20]

On 15 April, around 20 residents of the Tup village of Issyk-Kul Oblast attacked traffic police.Two officers were hospitalized. Reportedly the incident is related to an earlier accident that the inspectors were investigating. [size=around 20]

As reported on April 15th, Kyrgyz authorities have started closing madrassas (Islamic religious schools) operating without a state license across the country. Already 10 madrasas are closed, 20 have received prescriptions. Government says that the measure is a 'fight against terrorism and extremism'.

On 14 April, three police officers were beaten by an angry group of 30-40 villagers of Tup, Issyk-Kul region, after a high-speed chase led to the death of a driver and injuries of two passengers who crashed while on the run from the police. The police officers were hospitalized for their injuries. [size=a group of 30-40]

On 13 April, protesters gathered in Bishkek. The crowd consisted mostly of retailers from the bazaar in Osh, who were affected by recent fire in the market. They demanded legal and material assistance and better protection. [size=no report]
On 12 April, activists held a protest in the center of Bishkek against shooting stray animals in the city. According to the photos reported up to 10 protesters gathered. [size=up to 10]

On 11 April 2018, 20-30 residents of Boz-Adyr village in Batken district protested at the local administration against the assault of a fellow Kyrgyz villager by the Uzbek residents of Sokh exclave two days earlier with the demanding the Uzbek authorities to find the responsibles. The protestors also called Kyrgyz authorities to enforce restrictions on the movement of Sokh exclave residents through Boz-Adyr village. [size=20-30]
Government of Kyrgyzstan (2017-); Civilians (Kyrgyzstan); Civilians (China); Labour Group (China)

On 11 April, a violent rally took place in Toguz-Toru district (Kazarman municipality) of the Jalal-Abad region. A commission came to carry an inspection at a controversial gold mining factory and to meet with locals. About a thousand local residents gathered at the meeting. The people began to throw stones at the side of the commission and the police officers. Three policemen were injured. Property of the Chinese state-owned factory was set on fire and severely damaged. Later it was revealed that the plant was established illegally. [size=about a thousand]

On 11 April, young people and students organized a rally in Sarai municipality of Kara-Suu district, Osh region. They were protesting against religious radicalism and 'terrorism'. The exact number of protesters is not known. [size=no report]

On 10 April, protesters gathered near the embassy of Uzbekistan in Bishkek. They expressed their concerns regarding the investigation of recent fatal shooting of a Kyrgyz citizen on the Uzbek territory. The exact number of participants was not reported. [size=no report]

On 10 April 2018, 15-20 residents and rice farmers of Progress village in Uzgen district protested on the disputed land in the village against the local administration's plan to take a portion of their land away. Protesters accused town officials of corruption and land grabbing which violates land lease agreement that stated it was given to the villagers for 99 years. [size=15-20]
Military Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Border Service

On 7 April 2018, a Kyrgyz citizen was shot and killed by the Uzbek border guard on the undemarcated border in the Kyrgyz neighborhood of Mamay near the town of Kerben in Aksy district of Jalal-Abad region. Deadly incident took place when victim crossed the border from Uzbekistan into Kyrgyzstan after visiting his relatives on the Uzbek side. Uzbek Border service defended its border guard's action by indicating that Kyrgyz citizen ignored warnings prior to his death.

On 4 April, a group of 10 villagers severely beat a man in Boston, Nookat district [coded as Nookat], who came from a neighboring village to talk to a local girl. The girl was tied up as a punishment. [size=10]

On 4 April, law enforcers detained a man with hemophilia in Kyzyl-Kia over allegedly stolen mobile phone. Law enforcers used physical violence against the man in order to obtain confession and due to his diagnose he later fell into a coma and had to be hospitalized.

On 3 April, around 60 protesters gathered near the Pervomaysky district court, Bishkek, supporting the activist and journalist and demanding a fair trial for him. He was accused of calling for a coup and later found guilty and fined 50 000 som. [size= around 60]
Military Forces of Tajikistan (1994-) Border Service

On 3 April, residents of the village of Uch-Dobo, Batken region, clashed with locals of a neighboring Tajik village over a fence built across the settlement. Tajiks demanded to stop the construction. After the arrival of the district head, all left. Three men were injured and hospitalized, one of them a member of the Tajik border guard, who tried to calm the situation. The exact numbers of rioters involved is not known. [size=no report]

On 3 April, around 100 protesters gathered in the center of Bishkek. They were protesting against cutting down trees within the city, related to the ongoing reconstruction of streets, and resignation of the mayor. Participants claimed that they are ready to start an indefinite protest action soon, if their demands are not respected. [size=around 100]

On 3 April 2018, 20-30 passenger mini-bus drivers protested at the bus stop in the 11th micro-district in Bishkek city against the discrimination and excessive traffic violation fines demanding the city authorities cooperate with protesters and remove costly fines. [size=20-30]

On 2 April 2018, about 100 tanker truck drivers protested near the toll plaza in Sosnovka village of Chui region against police fines for absence of insurance policy which protesters insisted was aiding police corruption. Protesters urged the Kyrgyz government to revise the regulation and include the drivers' adjustments to the law requiring mandatory insurance. [size=about 100]

On 2 April 2018, 50-100 private bus drivers protested at the bus stop in 12th district of Bishkek city against police fines for absence of insurance policy. Protesters demanded the city administration suspend fines for private bus operators and increase bus fare within city limits. [size=50-100]

On 29 March 2018, about 100 medics, local officials and public activists demonstrated and marched through the business district of Batken town to raise awareness of spreading tuberculosis disease in the region and address lack of funding for the local tuberculosis hospital. [size=about 100]

On 29 March, a small group of protesters gathered for a picket protest in the center of Bishkek. As parents of disabled children, they demanded increase of social benefits and support. [size=a small group]

On 26 March 2018, 10-15 teachers of the Kyrgyz State National University protested near the dormitory 9 in Bishkek city refusing to vacate the university owned building and demanding electricity turned back on which was cut due to planned renovation. Protesters complained they have nowhere else to go with their families. [size=10-15]

On 25 March, two SWAT police officers burst into the apartment of Pakistani citizens in Bishkek, beat and handcuffed them, and extorted their cell phones and 2,000 dollars in cash. The two officers were later arrested.

On 23 March, a picket-flash mob took place in Bishkek. The gathering was called 'Know your rights' and was aimed to raise awareness among civilians about human rights and their political rights. Several dozens activists actively participated [size=several dozens].

On 17 March, a rally was held in the center of Bishkek. Protesters gathered to commemorate 'Aksy events' (violence against protesters in 2002) and demanded justice for the victims and punishment of perpetrators; and also to increase fight against corruption. The exact number of participants is not known [size=no report].

On 15 March, an inmate was beaten in a local temporary detention facility in Karakol by two police officers. He said that they tried to obtain his confession to a crime. Later he complained to media as well as to the local court and the law enforcers were charged with torture.

On 15 March, local teachers, students and their parents organized a protest in Issyk-Kul. They demanded proper administration of local educational events for students and youth, especially local sport competition, and complained about inactivity of responsible officials. [size=no report]

On 10 March 2018, 200-300 residents of Toguz-Toro district protested in the town of Kazarman against the gold processing plant project in the area demanding the Kyrgyz authorities shut it down due to environmental concerns. [size=200-300]
Women (Kyrgyzstan); BFI: Bishkek Feminist Initiatives Association

On 8 March, a women's march took place in Osh, Kyrgyzstan. The protesters voiced slogans regarding ending violence against women and discrimination and protecting their rights, and also other gender minorities. The event was organized by the BFI: Bishkek Feminist Initiatives Association and other local NGOs. [size=no report]
Women (Kyrgyzstan); BFI: Bishkek Feminist Initiatives Association

On 8 March, a women's march took place in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. The protesters voiced slogans regarding ending violence against women and discrimination and protecting their rights, and also other gender minorities. The event was organized by the BFI: Bishkek Feminist Initiatives Association and other local NGOs. [size=no report]

On 7 March 2018, 10-15 construction workers protested outside the State National Hospital on the corner of Moskovsky and Panfilov streets in Bishkek city demanding their wages from the contractor firm and hospital. [size=10-15]

On 5 March, around 200 protesters gathered in Bishkek, demanding judicial reforms and the dismissal of 'corrupt judges' by the President personally. Some of them also held portraits of alleged political prisoners. [size=around 200]

On 1 March, residents of Kazarman village, Toguz-Toru District, Jalal-Abad Oblast, organized a rally against the proposed gold mining plant, expressing their concerns about the environment. Around 150 protesters reported. Several protests regarding this plant had already happened earlier. [size=around 150]

On 1 March, residents of Toguz-Toro rayon [coded to Kazarman] demolished the fence of the local gold extraction plant. Out of about 500 rioters present, 150 further entered the area. Later they were calmed and left the area. Already earlier in February, peaceful rallies against the plant had been organized. Intervention of police forces was not reported. [size=about 500]

On 28 February 2018, about 30 employees of the Sulaiman-Too museum in Osh city of Osh region protested in the premises of the museum against the director accusing him of corruption, misconduct and abuse of power. Protesters demanded his resignation. [size=about 30]
On 27 February 2018, about 50 villagers in Kadamjai district protested near the village of Maidan against the Shambesai gold mining project due to environmental concerns. [size=about 50]

On 26 February, in Bishkek, an activist and a journalist Ondurush Toktonasyrov organized a picket protest near the building of the State Service for Combating Economic Crimes in support of another journalist, Elnura Alkanova. Alkanova is currently under investigation and the activist claimed the case illegal, demanding its immediate interruption. [size=no report]

On 22 February, residents of Chakmak-Suu, Chatkal district gathered to protest against the proposed construction of a waste deposit in the neighborhood, allegedly putting local water resources at a risk. [size=no report]

On 14 February 2018, about 50 supporters of 3 imprisoned Kyrgyz politicians protested outside the White House in Bishkek city demanding resignation of a chief of the country's security service accusing him of abuse of power while in office. [size=about 50]

On 13 February, protesters gathered in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, following Presidential announcement of investigation in power structures. They called for resignation of the Chief of the National Security Committee and declared support to three activists, imprisoned in 2016. [size=no report]

On 11 February, law enforcers in Osh reportedly tortured a local resident, in order to gain financial profit and confession in possession and distribution of drugs. Three other persons were arrested alongside with him, but torture against them was reportedly not used.
As reported on 8 February, three police officers broke in the apartment of a businessman in Bishkek, beat him, and robbed him of his valuables. They were later detained.

On 7 February, a rally was held in Bishkek to commemorate a human rights activist, who had died on 7th Feb. 2002 after 22nd day of the hunger strike, protesting against selling of a local business to a Chinese company. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Kyrgyzstan (2017-) State Committee for National Security

On February 7th, a special operation was held in the Sokuluk district of the Chui oblast against supporters of radical ideologies. Ammunition and various weapons were seized, as well as religious literature and other materials. The weapons belonged to four radicals, detained earlier in February.

On 7 February 2018, 500-1000 residents of Toguz-Toro district protested in the town of Kazarman against the gold processing plant project in the area due to environmental concerns demanding the Kyrgyz authorities shut down the plant. [size=500-1000]

On 7 February 2018, about 30 supporters of Kyrgyz female lawmaker Aida Salyanova from the Ata-Meken parliamentarian faction protested at the hearing in Bishkek city court against political persecution of opposition politicians in Kyrgyzstan and demanded from the prosecution to drop all charges against the lawmaker. [size=about 30]

On 6 February, local residents of several micro districts within Bishkek held a rally in front of the city hall. The picket protest was related to housing and rental issues. The exact number of protesters is not known. [size=no report]

Around 6 February 2018, about 3 police officers attacked and robbed a small retail business owner at his residence in Sverdlovsky district of Bishkek city prompting a criminal investigation into an incident with suspects being detained following victim's spouse report.

On 5 February, in Bishkek, supporters of three arrested politicians held a protest claiming that the imprisonment of the three was politically motivated. All three were detained in 2016. [size=no report]

On 2 February 2018, about 1000 residents of Kadamjai district protested near Maidan village against the Shambesai gold mining project expressing their concerns for pollution of the local river which is vital water source for surrounding villages in the area. [size=about 1000]

On 1 February, around 1000 residents of Kadamjai [coded to Kadamjai] district protested against a gold mine nearby claiming that the mine may harm the environment without providing real economic benefits. [size=around 1000]

On 1 February 2018, about 100 residents of Toguz-Toro district protested against the gold processing plant in Kazarman town demanding the Kyrgyz authorities shut down the project due to environmental concerns. [size=about 100]

On 31 January 2018, about 13 female protesters demonstrated outside the White House in Bishkek city appealing to the country's president and the Supreme Court for intervention in their court case regarding a dispute with the market owners in the town of Toktogul. [size=about 13]

On 26 January 2018, about 20 female protesters demonstrated at the district court in the town of Toktogul expressing their frustration with a judge who dismissed their appeal in their lawsuit against local market owners whom the protesters accused of forging records and documents to take away their retail shops. [size=about 20]

On 24 January 2018, about 20 residents of Jalal-Abad city gathered at the Mayor's Office to protest against the plan to raise water fees, which protesters complained was unaffordable for many residents. Protesters demanded the city administration to address their concerns or they will take the issue up with the central government. [size=about 20]

On 20 January, protesters from Sokuluk and Alamudun districts, Chui region, gathered in the center of Bishkek. They demanded to meet with the deputy Prime Minister and discuss with him some particular issues related to a proposed land reform and insufficient infrastructure. [size=no report]

On 15 January 2018, around 300 protesters gathered in the village Oruktu, Ala-Buka district demanding the Chinese-owned gold mining company settles outstanding social package taxes with the local township after which the mining operation can be resumed. [size=around 300]

On 11 January 2018, about 30 residents of Chechme village in Kadamjai district of Batken region protested against the border delimitation commission's proposal to transfer local spring over to Sokh exclave of Uzbekistan, which has sparked disapproval among villagers demanding to keep water source in the Kyrgyz territory. [size=about 30]
As announced on January 8th, the court in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan decided to block 159 websites, allegedly related to 'extremism'. Several other websites were closed down already earlier in 2017.

On 8 January, a rally of doctors of the metropolitan hospital was organized in Bishkek. The personnel of the facility demanded resignation of the director. The ministry of Health declared that they are ready to involve in the issue. [size=no report]

On 7 January, about 100 people held an anti-China protest on Ala-Too square in Bishkek against the detainment of ethnic Kyrgyz in 're-education' camps in Xinjiang and against illegal Chinese citizens residing in Kyrgyzstan. [size=about 100]

On January 4th, a fire occurred in a local Baptist church in Kadji-Say, Kyrgyzstan, Ton region. Because conflicts between Muslims and Christians had happened earlier and a 'Molotov cocktail' was reportedly used, police started investigation of a possible crime. No casualties reported.

On 1 January, residents of Kazarman, Toguz-Toru district, gathered to protest against a gold mine nearby claiming that the mine may harm the environment without providing real economic benefits. [size=no report]
